launchA SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket is prepped for launch‚ÄúWe thought it‚Äôs about time for a change, and we want to get little Israel all the way to the moon,‚Äù said Yonatan Winetraub, co-founder of Israel‚Äôs SpaceIL, a nonprofit organisation behind the effort.&nbspThe moon, nearly full and glowing brightly, beckoned as it rose in the eastern sky. Within an hour of liftoff, Beresheet was already sending back data and had successfully deployed its landing legs, according to SpaceIL.&nbsp‚ÄúWe‚Äôll keep analysing the data, but bottom line is we entered the very exclusive group of countries that have launched a spacecraft to the moon,‚Äù said Yigal Harel, head of SpaceIL‚Äôs spacecraft programme.&nbspElon Musk‚Äôs SpaceX to have launches reviewed by PentagonElon Musk reveals price of a ticket to Mars on board SpaceX flightsPrime minister Benjamin Netanyahu was watching the launch live from the Israeli control centre in Yehud, near Tel Aviv.&nbsp‚ÄúThis is a big step for Israel, but a giant step for Israeli technology,‚Äù he said.The four-legged Beresheet, barely the size of a washing machine, will circle Earth in ever bigger loops until it‚Äôs captured by lunar gravity and goes into orbit around the moon. Touchdown would be 11 April&nbspat the Sea of Serenity.&nbspNasa‚Äôs Apollo missions in the 1960s and 1970s took about three days to get astronauts to the moon, but they used monstrous Saturn V rockets.The $100m (¬£78m)&nbspBeresheet mission could not&nbspafford its own rocket ‚Äì even a little one ‚Äì so the organisers opted for a ride share. That makes for a much longer trip the moon&nbspis currently nearly 230,000 miles&nbspaway.&nbsp‚ÄúThis is Uber-style space exploration, so we‚Äôre riding shotgun on the rocket,‚Äù Mr Winetraub explained at a news conference on the eve of launch.&nbspThe US&nbspAir Force also has a small research spacecraft aboard the rocket, for a one-year mission in orbit around Earth.&nbspCreated with Sketch.SpaceX's journey through the Solar System  Show all 6Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.The Soviet Union was the first to put a spacecraft on the moon, Luna 2, in 1959. Nasa&nbspfollowed with the Ranger 4 spacecraft in 1962. Last month, China became the first country to land on the far side of the moon.&nbspApollo 11 astronaut&nbspBuzz Aldrin quickly offered congratulations following Thursday‚Äôs launch. So did Nasa&nbspadministrator Jim Bridenstine, who called it ‚Äúa historic step for all nations and commercial space as we look to extend our collaborations beyond low-Earth orbit and on to the moon‚Äù.&nbspNasa&nbsphas a laser reflector aboard Beresheet and is offering its Deep Space Network for communication.&nbsp‚ÄúAll the best to @TeamSpaceIL as it starts its journey tonight on a @SpaceX #Falcon9 from Florida to my old stomping ground ... the moon,‚Äù Aldrin tweeted.&nbspThe Beresheet mission originally was part of the Google Lunar XPrize competition and even made the final cut before the contest ended last year without a winner. The organisers decided to press ahead on their own, with donations from billionaires as well as schoolchildren.&nbspLunar surface operations are meant to last just two days. Beresheet will measure the magnetic field at the landing site, and send back data and pictures. A time capsule is aboard the lander ‚Äî which includes a picture of Israeli astronaut Ilan Ramon, who died aboard space shuttle Columbia in 2003 ‚Äî as well as a lunar library containing 30 million pages on a disk from the US-based Arch Mission Foundation.&nbspRamon‚Äôs widow, Rona, was a big supporter of Beresheet she died of cancer in December.&nbspFollowing liftoff, SpaceX recovered the first-stage booster, which flew twice last year. The booster landed smoothly on an offshore ocean platform, after the hottest re-entry yet, according to SpaceX founder and chief executive Elon Musk. Sparks from burning metal were visible in the landing video.&nbspMr Musk said the booster will fly a fourth time in April, during a launch abort test of the new crew Dragon capsule. SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsPrice rises necessary to ensure a universal postal service can be maintained, Royal Mail saidClick to followThe IndependentRoyal Mail is raising prices after struggling to meet its targets to slash costs, achieving just ¬£100m of a forecast ¬£230m last yearRoyal Mail will hike the price of first class stamps by 3p to 70p from next month while second class will go up by 3p to 61p, the privatised postal company announced on Friday.The increases will be introduced on 25 March and come on top of changes Royal Mail is making to its redirection service, announced earlier this year.From next month, Royal Mail will charge for the number of customers who want their post redirected, rather than on a per-surname basis.Price rises are necessary to ensure a universal postal service can be maintained, Royal Mail said.The company added: ‚ÄúRoyal Mail understands that many companies and households are finding it hard in the current economic environment.‚ÄúAs a result, we have considered any pricing changes very carefully and in doing so have sought to minimise any impact on our customers.‚ÄùRoyal Mail is raising prices after struggling to meet its targets to slash costs, achieving just ¬£100m of a forecast ¬£230m last year.More than ¬£1bn was wiped off the company‚Äôs value in October after it warned last year that falling letter volumes would hit profits.The company‚Äôs half-year adjusted earnings fell by over a quarter and headline pre tax profits by more than half. Shares slumped again in january after another disappointing update.It emerged last year that new chief executive Rico Back had received a ¬£6m payment when he joined from General Logistics Systems, a Dutch firm that Royal Mail owns.His total pay packet for this year could hit ¬£2.7m while outgoing chief executive Moya Greene received a ¬£900,000 payout.We‚Äôll tell you what‚Äôs true. title: brexit trade deal liam fox global britain japan turkey explained
story: IM Subscribe &nbsp registerIM SubscribeCreated with Sketch.IM Join us? Subscribe &nbsp registerIM Join us? SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.Analysis:&nbspWith just six of 40 agreements signed off, Ben Chapman looks at whether the international trade secretary is at faultClick to followThe IndependentOne second after Brexit, all 40 of the EU‚Äôs trade deals will be rolled over and replaced with UK-specific versions. Or at least that‚Äôs what we were told by Liam Fox in 2017.The confidence beaming from the international trade secretary as he set off on his world tour to convince governments to do business with ‚Äúglobal Britain‚Äù was notably absent this week.With little to show for his efforts, Fox&nbspwas&nbspforced into an embarrassing climbdown, finally conceding that many of those&nbsptrade deals had no chance of being ratified by 29 March.&nbspSo where are we now ‚Äì and why has Liam Fox fallen so far short of his own bar?No deal will be done in time with valuable trading partners Turkey and Japan, nor with the tiny European principalities of Andorra and San Marino.&nbspCan UK continue trading with countries covered by an EU trade deal?Fox has so far delivered just six of the 40 deals he promised. The biggest positive he can point to is an agreement with Switzerland, a country which took ¬£20bn of UK exports in 2017.By comparison, the UK shipped ¬£278bn of goods and services to the EU in 2017. A deal with the trading bloc, Fox told us, would be ‚Äúthe easiest in human history‚Äù.&nbspThe only other agreements he has so far been able to finalise in close to three years of toil account for a tiny percentage of UK trade. Israel is the largest among these, buying ¬£2.4bn of UK goods and services, with ¬£1.6bn flowing the other way.Agreements sealed with the Palestinian territories&nbspand the Faroe Islands will do little to keep post-Brexit Britain afloat. We also have a deal with the 21 countries which make up the Common Market for&nbspEastern and Southern Africa, but only Egypt accounts for anything more than a negligible amount of UK trade.Among the remaining countries in the group are two, which, according to official figures, imported no UK goods last year: Eritrea and Comoros.There is of course a chance that agreements will be reached in the next 35 days but Fox‚Äôs announcement hardly inspires confidence.He attempted to reassure the public with news that formal agreements are close with Fiji and Papua New Guinea.&nbspBut that&nbspsimply served&nbspto highlight the lack of progress on agreements with far more important trading partners.True, we have some form of agreement with the US, Australia and New Zealand but these mostly cover product standards. They aren‚Äôt full trade deals.Created with Sketch. Juergen Ziegler, CEO for Europe, said that while Brexit was not the only factor, it has brought forward the decision to relocate‚ÄúParticularly intensive discussions‚Äù are happening with the European Economic Area, South African Customs Unions, Canada and South Korea, the trade secretary says ‚Äì which sounds distinctly like they won‚Äôt be signed in time.It all seems like tinkering around the edges when you compare the figures involved to the vast sums of trade we conduct&nbspwith the other 27 EU member states.None of this is to say that our trade secretary has been incompetent or lazy. No one said rearranging the deck chairs on the Titanic was easy.&nbspAnd negotiating trade deals is&nbspeven more fiendishly complex ‚Äì they frequently&nbspamount to hundreds of clauses covering standards and tariffs on vast&nbspnumbers of products.Deals often take&nbspyears to finalise, even for skilled negotiators focused on one agreement, let alone 40.Whether through arrogance or ignorance, Liam Fox did not listen to trade experts who said dozens of EU deals could not be ‚Äúrolled over‚Äù with ease.&nbspHe assured everyone it could be done, but that was never truly the case.Got an unanswered question about Brexit? title: charter flights deport families uk immigration home office jamaica
story: IM Subscribe &nbsp registerIM SubscribeCreated with Sketch.IM Join us? Subscribe &nbsp registerIM Join us? SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.Click to followThe IndependentTwenty-nine iniduals were deported to Jamaica on 6 February in a move that was described as a ‚Äúslap in the face‚Äù for Britain‚Äôs Caribbean community, 10 months after the Windrush scandal broke last AprilA 12-year-old girl brought a room of adults close to tears this week when she read out a letter about the impact of immigration controls against her&nbspfather.‚ÄúImagine waking up at 5am to flashing lights and a very loud banging noise at the door,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúImagine seeing 20 to 30 men rushing into your home just for one man. Having to say bye to my dad when he‚Äôs in handcuffs just hurts my heart. It‚Äôs like immigration doesn‚Äôt want my family to succeed.‚ÄùDuring a meeting at the Jamaican High Commission, the child ‚Äì&nbspsurrounded by her three sisters, the youngest just a toddler, and mother ‚Äì delivered a moving testimony that shed light on the impact of immigration control on families.The meeting took place two weeks after&nbspa charter flight taking 29 iniduals from the UK to Jamaica prompted outrage in the wake of the Windrush scandal. Commissioner Seth George Ramocan organised the gathering in the hope that it would&nbsphelp&nbspinform discussions about how they cooperate with the Home Office on future deportations.But there was little discussion about policy or intergovernmental cooperation. From the outset, the meeting was highly charged with emotion, with&nbsprelatives giving&nbspheart-rending accounts of having their loved ones ‚Äúsnatched‚Äù from them and sent against their will to a country that, often, they barely knew or remembered.The mother of one man who was on the charter flight ‚Äì after coming to the UK aged 11 ‚Äì&nbspexplained how her son had arrived in Jamaica with no one to care for him, and made a passionate plea that ‚Äúall of our children who came here when they were young should be here. This is degrading. Our children need to come back.‚ÄùWith so many relatives already driven to despair and desperation over the Home Office‚Äôs treatment of their loved ones, there was little the commissioner could say to temper them. It was clear that they had little faith in anything he said.This comes as no&nbspsurprise when you consider that many of these people have suffered years of fear and hopelessness at the hands of the British government, despite never being subjected to immigration control themselves.We can debate the use of&nbspcharter flights&nbspand the wider&nbsphostile environment as forms of immigration control,&nbspbut whether&nbspenough attention is paid to the indirect devastation this has on their loved ones is another question.We‚Äôll tell you what‚Äôs true. SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsCreated with Sketch.With a new group of MPs&nbsptaking defectors from both sides of the aisle, Ashley Cowburn looks the impact on Theresa May‚Äôs bid for a deal with BrusselsClick to followIndy PoliticsThough they have not yet formed a political party, the Independent Group has more MPs than the Democratic Unionist Party and the same number as the Liberal DemocratsWhen Sky News‚Äôs helicopter circles above Westminster, it is usually a reliable sign of political turmoil. The same can be said for an unusually high number of gazebos on College Green ‚Äì the patch of grass outside the House of Lords from which journalists broadcast to the nation.This week an aerial view of the Palace of Westminster was beamed into living rooms across the country as another dramatic week in British politics unfolded.At 10am on Monday, seven MPs quit Jeremy Corbyn‚Äòs Labour Party with a withering assessment of his leadership ‚Äì the biggest schism in the party since the formation of the Social Democratic Party (SDP) in the 1980s.May eyes potential route out of Brexit deadlock in BrusselsPost-Brexit Britain won‚Äôt have any trade links left at this rateEU‚Äôs Juncker says he is not optimistic about avoiding no-deal BrexitBarclays sets aside ¬£150m to prepare for Brexit falloutThe following evening, an eighth MP left Labour‚Äôs ranks and on Wednesday ‚Äì an hour before prime minister‚Äôs questions ‚Äì Anna Soubry, Sarah Wollaston and Heidi Allen left the Conservative Party to join the opposition benches.Together, the 11 MPs have formed the Independent Group in the House of Commons and, though they have not yet formed a political party, the group has more MPs than the Democratic Unionist Party and the same number as the Liberal Democrats.It means Theresa May‚Äòs effective majority in the chamber has been reduced to eight, making her reliance on the DUP to prop up the government ever more important.While this week has undoubtedly increased the instability at Westminster, the parliamentary arithmetic for Brexit hasn‚Äôt shifted a great deal.&nbspCreated with Sketch.Labour split: the reaction on Twitter Show all 16Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.The prime minister still faces the mammoth task of getting her deal through the Commons and, regardless of which side of the Commons the three ex-Tory MPs are sitting on, it is unlikely they will suddenly drop their opposition to Ms May‚Äôs deal.Support for a fresh referendum still does not appear to command a majority in the chamber, and the likelihood of the prime minister declaring her support for a customs union (one of Labour‚Äôs red lines) remains slim at best.But the current turmoil will inevitably have a considerable impact on the debate. The hardline Brexiteer Conservative MPs in the European Research Group ‚Äì wary of the effect more defections from the party could have ‚Äì may provide the prime minister with a temporary show of unity as she continues to negotiate with Brussels.And with just 36 days&nbspuntil Brexit, wavering Labour MPs wanting to avoid a no-deal scenario may feel more inclined to back Ms May‚Äôs proposals. Further votes may take place the following day.However many, including Sir Keir Starmer, Labour‚Äôs shadow Brexit secretary, believe Ms May&nbspis planning to delay the meaningul vote until after the European Council meeting on 21 and 22 March, even if an extension to the Article 50 deadline of 29 March&nbspis offered.Labour MP David Lammy said: ‚ÄúIt is in those final days that we have the biggest chance to convince MPs to give this decision back to the public.‚ÄùWhat will the march be demanding?The key demand is that&nbspany Brexit deal should be put to a public vote for final approval.‚ÄúInstead of letting Theresa May kick the can down the road until the March 29 deadline, hundreds of thousands of people will march on parliament offering a solution to a crisis that threatens our rights, our living standards and our environment,‚Äù said former Green Party leader Caroline Lucas.One proposal for avoiding a no-deal Brexit and securing a second referendum involves tabling&nbspan amendment&nbspin the last week before 29 March.MPs would then approve her deal only if it was subject to a public vote.Where&nbspwill the march take place?The march is set to begin at 12pm, or ‚Äúhigh noon‚Äù, on Saturday 23 March, on London‚Äôs Park Lane.Organisers from the People‚Äôs Vote campaign&nbsphave not yet released full details of the route but the march is due to end at Parliament Square with a ‚Äúmass rally and keynote speeches‚Äù.Who will be joining the march?Several leading politicians&nbspincluding Caroline Lucas,&nbspDavid Lammy, Liberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable, Conservative MP Anna Soubry, and the leaders of the SNP and Plaid Cymru in Westminster, Ian Blackford and Liz Saville Roberts, have already confirmed their support.&nbspThe Independent&nbspis supporting the march and encouraging readers to attend.The organisers are hoping to widen their appeal beyond those who have previously supported the People‚Äôs Vote and Final Say campaigns.&nbspThe Independent‚Äòs petition calling on the prime minister to give the people a final say on Brexit has attracted well over 1.1 million sigantures.‚ÄúThe only way forward out of this SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsFollow for live updates from WestminsterClick to followIndy PoliticsJohn McDonnell has insisted that Labour is ‚Äúmoving towards‚Äù supporting a second referendum as the party seeks to stem the flow of defections over Brexit.The shadow chancellor spoke out at the end of a&nbspdramatic week when 8 Labour MPs and 3 Tories broke away to form the Independent Group, in protest at the leadership of both parties.Dudley North MP Ian Austin became the ninth MP to quit Labour on&nbspFriday over its&nbsphandling of antisemitism&nbspallegations - but he said he had no plans to join the breakaway group.Meanwhile,&nbspTheresa May&nbsphas been warned she faces a major Tory rebellion unless she takes a no-deal Brexit off the table ahead of&nbspanother set of key votes on the UK‚Äôs withdrawal from the European Union.See below for live updatesIan Austin becomes ninth Labour MP to quit ‚Äòbroken‚Äô party this weekPM facing major rebellion from Tories unless no-deal taken off tableChance for Final Say vote to be missed with no-one committed to bring plan forwardTheresa May&nbspto hold weekend talks with Tusk on sidelines of Egypt summitLeave voters backed&nbspBrexit&nbspbecause they wanted to reduce the number of different coloured faces on their street, a Liberal Democrat MSP said.Alex Cole-Hamilton said a fury over immigration was behind many people voting to leave the European Union in the 2016 referendum.And he said that if the UK did withdraw from the EU, Lib Dems would automatically campaign for the country's re-entry.Jeremy&nbspCorbyn&nbsphas insisted there is no wide scale problem of bullying within the Labour Party.In an interview with Sky News, Mr&nbspCorbyn&nbspsaid that bad behaviour in the party was dealt with.There is no place for harshness, bullying or anything else in the party. I don't believe that it exists on a wide scale. Where there is bad behaviour, we deal with it. Where there is a problem, we deal with it.Mr&nbspCorbyn&nbsprejected claims by deputy leader Tom Watson that bullying was an issue in the party.The news has been dominated today by Ian Austin's decision to quit the Labour Party over antisemitism. Here's a helpful profile of the Dudley North MP by PA.Ian&nbspAustin's long-running battle with Jeremy Corbyn over antisemitism in the Labour Party has been shaped by his background as the adopted son of a Jewish father forced to flee the Nazis.Before being elected as MP for Dudley North in 2005, he was an adviser to then-chancellor Gordon Brown.His alliance with Mr Brown continued when he entered parliament, becoming his ministerial aide and then a minister for West Midlands regional affairs.The close political relationship led Tory leader David Cameron to brand him one of Mr Brown's boot boys.Mr&nbspAustin, 53, also served on the opposition front benches under Ed Miliband.He was never likely to see eye-to-eye with Mr Corbyn, a leader from the left of the party who made no secret of his discontent with the Blair-Brown New Labour era.The issue of antisemitism, which has dogged Mr Corbyn's leadership, was the main focus of tensions between the pair.Mr&nbspAustin's Jewish father Fred was 10 when the Nazis marched into Ostrava in what was then&nbspCzechoslovakia.Four days later he was put on a train to England - the only member of his family able to leave - and he never saw them again.He grew up to become a headmaster and adopted four children - including Mr&nbspAustin.This background had a profound influence on Mr&nbspAustin&nbspand was cited as his main reason for quitting LabourI grew up listening to my dad - a refugee from the Holocaust - teaching me about the evils of hatred and prejudice, he said.One of the main reasons I joined the Labour Party as a teenager here in Dudley more than 35 years ago was to fight racism, and I could never have believed that I'd be leaving because of racism, too.His relationship with the Labour leadership was strained for months before he took the decision to quit.In 2018, Mr&nbspAustin&nbspfound himself facing an internal investigation over alleged abusive behaviour during the party's anti-Semitism crisis.The probe into the heated discussion he had with party chairman&nbspIan&nbspLavery was eventually dropped.Tory rebel Dominic Grieve is among the Conservatives threatening to quit if the prime minister pursues a no-deal Brexit.He told the BBC: I can't predict where I might be if the party goes completely off the rails - that's another matter.The government which I am supporting implementing a no-deal Brexit - what would I do? I would not be able to maintain my support of the government. I would have to leave the party.Jeremy Corbyn in Brussels on Thursday (Reuters)Jeremy Corbyn will lay out his Brexit plans at a meeting of the Party of European Socialists in Madrid.&nbspThe labour leader is expected to hold talks with Spanish prime minister Pedro Sanchez at the event.&nbsp‚ÄúThe damaging deadlock on Brexit must be broken and following my discussions with European Union leaders and officials, I am in no doubt that Labour's alternative plan is credible and could be negotiated with the EU,‚Äù Mr Corbyn said.Please allow a moment for the live stream&nbspto loadWe‚Äôll tell you what‚Äôs true. title: r kelly accusations dropped rca music label
story: Heres what you need to know about the accusations andhes been dropped from his music label.The I believe I can fly singer has faced allegations of sexual misconduct.He was acquitted in  on charges of making child pornography, despite a videotape of an alleged encounter with a -year-old girl being shown to prosecutors.R Kelly has denied recent claims he is holding young women against their will in a one-man sex cult.Parents reportedly told police¬†that the star, real name Robert Kelly, is keeping six young women at his properties in Atlanta and Chicago, reported Buzzfeed.It‚Äôs reported they‚Äôre only allowed to use mobile phones provided by Kelly, must call him ‚Äúdaddy,‚Äù and can only eat, sleep or wash when he lets them.Kelly also films their sexual encounters, the reports claimed.One young woman Joycelyn Savage¬†has said she is safe and ‚Äúin a happy place‚Äù¬†after her family alleged¬†she was being held by him¬†at a secret location in Atlanta.She¬†insisted to TMZ that she was fine but refused to answershe was free to come and go.Jerhonda Pace¬†claims she had underage sex with R Kelly¬†at the age of  and was trained to please him.She alleges the singer would physically harm her and lock her in a room for days as punishment.He was then¬†accused of infecting Faith Rodgers, , with an STD on purpose.She was reportedly in a eight-month relationship with him after meeting him at a concert in San Antonio, Texas and¬†filed the lawsuit for willfully, deliberately and maliciously infecting her with herpes.Kelly has firmly denied these allegations.He said they have left him heartbroken and has criticised the media for trying to distort and destroy his legacy with claims that he sexually mistreats women.In January , the Surviving R Kelly docuseries aired in the US and featured accounts of alleged female victims who waived their right to anonymity¬†to claim they were sexually abused, bullied into threesomes, impregnated, held prisoner and beaten for looking at other men.In the series,¬†backing singer Jovante Cunningham claims that, like so many of Kelly‚Äôs young lovers, she was lured from outside her school¬†to ‚Äúhang out‚Äù at the star‚Äôs Chicago music studio where women lay on beds around the property simply waiting for him.Another backing singer, Lizzette Martinez, met R Kelly when she was . After making one of his regular visits to the mall to scout for young girls, she says he took a shine to her.R Kellys collaborator Lovell Jones alleged his taste in younger women was common knowledge in the camp.He said the singer would ask him to find girls that looked young at after-show parties.R Kelly has been¬†charged with ten counts of aggravated criminal sexual abuse.The singer is set to appear in court on March , the¬†Chicago SunTimes¬†reported citing court records.While no official comment has been made by either R Kelly or RCA- which is owned by Sony - several reports have been made claiming the music label has cut ties with the singer.Following the broadcast of the bombshell docuseries, R Kelly no longer features on the list of the labels artists.Variety, quoting an unidentied source, said Sony Music had decided to dissolve its working relationship with Kelly, but that no external announcement would be made.Billboard reported that the musician and the record company had agreed to part ways, citing unnamed sources.It said Kellys catalogue would remain with RCA. His music is still available on digital retailers and streaming services.

title: pound euro exchange rate brexit february 5

But as the clock ticks down, that optimism is likely to fade, Hardman noted.Before the EU referendum in June  a pound was trading for around ‚Ç¨.. Sterling fell around  per cent after the result.The highest rate in recent years was ‚Ç¨. in November .Foreign exchangemarkets allow currencies to be bought and sold around the world.They are necessary for international commerce but are also opportunities for traders to make a profit by effectively gambling on whether rates go up or down.As in any market, rates are determined by the price that buyers and sellers are willing to accept.If more people are buying than selling the price will go up, and vice versa.Traders confidence in a countrys economic health is the biggest factor shaping forex markets.Reports and forecasts on GDP growth, inflation, employment, retail sales and manufacturing can prompt traders to buy or sell a countrys currency.Other factors that sway forex markets title: labour historic split 100 mps ed miliband yvettte cooper face being ousted
story: Several party moderates are expected to announce theyre quitting as soon as TODAY.The group are furious at Jeremy Corbyn‚Äôs failure to get a grip on the anti-Semitism crisis or publicly campaign for a second referendum.And they fear they will fall victim to a massive purge by new left-wing activists who have flooded the party.Leading MPs including Ed Miliband and Yvette Cooper are feared to be among those at risk of deselection, The Daily Mail reported.In total  Labour MPs could face local bids to boot them out ‚Äì and around a quarter are expected to lose.It comes amid reports that former Labour leadership contender Chuka Umunna is preparing to lead a group to split from the party today.Roughly half a dozen MPs are holding a press conference this morning which could be the moment of truth.One of the potential splitters has reportedly told colleagues thatthey walk away they want to ‚Äúburn the house down‚Äù on their way out.Its not known whether they are planning to set up a new centrist party, or to sit as independents.The split will revive memories of the s Social Democratic Party, which was set up by a group of Labour rebels fed up with left-wing leader Michael Foot.The SDP briefly came close to winning a General Election, before fizzling out and merging with the Liberals to form the modern-day Lib Dems.Rumours of a Labour breakaway have swirled ever since Jeremy Corbyn became the party leader in .But ramped-up talk of deselection could have sped up the process.Moves to deselect MPs do not usually happen until shortly before a general election, next due in .But Labour‚Äôs general secretary Jennie Formby has already begun talks on setting the timetable ‚Äì raising fears a purge is looming.John McDonnell ‚Äì Corbyn‚Äôs closest ally ‚Äì yesterday warned Labour MPs not to quit.He told the BBC‚Äôs Andrew Marr Show: It would be like the s. My constituency in Hayes and Harlington, we had a Labour MP join the SDP and we lost the seat to the Conservatives.‚ÄúAnd it basically installed Mrs Thatcher in power for that decade.‚Äù

title: labour party split mps resign independent group
story: Now a ninth MP has joined the breakaway Independent Group, who quit in protest at Jeremy Corbyns handling of Brexit and anti-Semitism. Heres the lowdown.On February , , seven MPs held a press conference to announce they were quitting the Labour party.It was the most signicant breakaway since the formation of the Social Democratic Party in the early s.On February  a ninth MP also quit and joined their group.The rebels are:They are furious at Jeremy Corbyns Brexit stance and his handling of the anti-Semitism scandal that still dogs the party.Jewish MP Luciana Berger - who has faced vicious abuse from left-wingers -¬†said: I cannot remain in a party that I have come to the sickening conclusion is institutionally anti-Semitic.Chris Leslie said the party had been hijacked by the machine politics of the hard left.And Mr Gapes blasted: I am sickened that the Labour Party is now a racist and anti-Semitic party.The seven rebels from the centrist wing of the Labour party¬†have called themselves The Independent Group.It¬†already has a website although it had no content at the time of the announcement.Its Twitter account racked up more than , followers in the first hour after it was opened.It is thought they will sit as independents in the House of Commons, rather than forming an official party at this stage.Mr Umunna, seen as the most likely leader of the group, said: Fundamental change is needed.The established parties are not up to this change. They can‚Äôt be the change as they have become the problem.On February  Joan Ryan, chairman of Labour Friends of Israel,¬†also quit the party over¬†Jeremy Corbyns failure to deal with face of evil anti-Semitism.She slammed the Labour leader and the Stalinist clique that surrounds him and said he was not fit to be prime minister.Rumours of a pending split in the Labour party have swirled since Jeremy Corbyn became leader in .And speculation reached a frenzy over the weekend amid reports a group of¬†MPs would finally stage a walkout and launch a breakaway party.The confirmation by the seven rebels came after reports Labour moderates had reached breaking point over Jeremy Corbyns Brexit stance, particularly his refusal to back a second referendum.Former frontbencher Chuka Umunna said on Thursday he did not ‚Äúgive a damn... about keeping any party together‚Äù when compared to the overriding priority of the national interest in avoiding a No Deal¬†Brexit.And ex-shadow chancellor Chris Leslie told the House of Commons Labour supporters are being ‚Äúplayed for fools‚Äù by the leadership.On Friday, Edinburgh South MP Ian Murray said MPs were being pushed to the brink.Mr Murray refused to sign a provocative pledge shared on social media as part of efforts to shore up party unity, insisting his loyalty was not in question.He insisted his loyalty to Labour was not in question.On Sunday shadow chancellor John McDonnell warned a split would cost seats like the SDP breakaway in , which installed Mrs Thatcher in power for a decade.He told the BBC: I dont think any of the people whove even been mentioned about this split would want that.Former party deputy chairman Michael Dugher revealed in the Sun on Sunday on February  he was quitting Labour after  years because of anti-Semitism.He said: ‚ÄúIt pains me to see what the Labour party has become.I can no longer justy paying subs to a party which I now regard as institutionally anti-Semitic.Mr Dugher stood down as an MP at the last election, but current MPs have long been said to be close to quitting and Brexit could be the tipping point for some.Up to  current MPs fear they will fall victim to a massive purge by new left-wing activists who have flooded the party.Ed Miliband and Yvette Cooper are among those said to be at risk of deselection.Some may decide to jump before they are pushed, switching to a new centrist party that has long been touted in Westminster.Moderates and Remainers have called on the Labour leader to throw his weight behind calls for a second referendum.Until Feb , fed-up MPs have shied away from quitting but the decision threw the party leadership into fresh turmoil.One of the potential splitters has reportedly told colleagues thatthey walk away they want to ‚Äúburn the house down‚Äù on their way out.They will hope backbench colleagues will follow them out the door, Westminster watchers say.Another crunch point could come ahead of a Commons vote on February  on Theresa Mays Brexit plans.Some backbenchers are reportedly planning to submit an amendment calling for a Peoples Vote, which is not sanctioned by the party leadership.Sources claim ten more Labour MPs are ready to quit and join The Independent Group, plus six Tories could join them.One senior Labour figure said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a matter of time before others go.‚ÄúI think you‚Äôll see another ten at least leave Labour in a matter of weeks.‚ÄúThe Independents could be the fourth biggest political party by Easter Sunday.‚ÄùOne insider added that he also expected Labour peers Waheed Alli, Margaret McDonagh, John Reid to sit as Independents in the Lords.In a sign of Labour‚Äôs sht under Mr Corbyn, it separately emerged on Monday, February , that s militant Derek Hatton was back as a Labour party member after a  year exile.If Labour splitters started their own party, it would likely aim for the centre-left ground formerly occupied by Tony Blairs New Labour.They would pursue social democratic policies and would be against a hard Brexit, and possibly hoping to reverse Brexit altogether.As well as Labour MPs, the breakaway party would hope to attract Lib Dems and pro-EU Tories.But they would face a struggle to make an impact as the electoral odds are against smaller and less established parties.Part of the reason is the first-past-the-post voting system in general elections, which favours the two biggest parties.In  an alliance of the SDP - formed by breakaway Labour politicians - and the old Liberal party won more than  per cent of votes nationally but only  seats.Our journalists title: independents cant reverse brexit democracy
story: But there is a fatal flaw in the Remainers‚Äô pitch to the nation.You cannot ‚Äúbuild a new politics‚Äù when your foundation stone is an attempt to reverse the biggest democratic mandate in our history.That is not a respectable position. And it immediately repels .million Leavers, plus many Remainers who know the referendum result must be fulfilled.Nor can you credibly demand a ¬≠second Brexit vote while refusing to call by-elections in your own seats.‚Äã‚ÄãIn  these MPs won majorities for Labour on Corbyn‚Äôs pro-Brexit manesto. They have dumped both.They cannot argue Britain needs another referendum without accepting that their own constituencies have a far more urgent claim for a second vote on them.All that said, we did not disagree with a word as they tore apart Corbyn, his Communist acolytes and the vicious hard-Left sycophants whose sanctimonious hatred pollutes public debate.Labour is now a racist party. Its deranged economics would reduce us to hardship beyond Britain‚Äôs experience.It loathes the West and sides instinctively with our enemies, even terrorists.But The Sun has said all this from the moment Corbyn became leader in .Why did it take Brexit for the Seven to finally walk  How could they stomach the rest of it so long That goes tenfold for the scores of Corbyn-hating ‚Äúmoderates‚Äù still left. How can Tom Watson remain deputy leader of a regime he now publicly denounces What is Yvette Cooper smokingshe believes she has a place in Corbyn‚Äôs ‚Äúbroad church‚Äù  It is a church so narrow only Corbyn worshippers get a pew.Her party is over. It will never magically be handed back to Cooper and her pals. They are on borrowed time until Momentum oust the lot.Yet in a snap election they would lie to you that this man they despise and distrust will make a fine Prime Minister.Those more principled and brave, Jewish MP Luciana Berger especially, have finally leapt into the unknown.Brexit aside, good luck to them.Now the leboat is launched, it‚Äôs time the others clambered aboard.LABOUR is in disarray. But things could soon be worse for the Tories.Six of Theresa May‚Äôs Remainer backbenchers could join the new gang.That‚Äôs bad enough. Butthe Tories do not deliver Brexit on or soon after March  they could split in half, only to be eaten alive by Nigel Farage‚Äôs new party.That‚Äôs why they cannot afford to let Remainers steal Brexit negotiations from the Government and postpone it.And why backbench Brexiters MUST be sensible when changes to the backstop come.It‚Äôs compromise, or catastrophe.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour split echoes of 1981s gang of four
story: At the very moment when the Government is in meltdown over Brexit, his party is tearing itself apart. The gaping wounds left by this internal conflict could soon prove fatal to him.There were sharp intakes of breath yesterday when seven moderate Labour MPs announced they have resigned to set up a new Independent Group.Their number may be small ‚Äî and none of them, except perhaps Chuka Umunna, may be household names ‚Äî but their move is certain to have a huge impact on British politics.It throws the Opposition into chaos.¬† Beleaguered by dismal poll ratings, serial incompetence, isions over Brexit and accusations of extremism, Corbyn will now come under brutal pressure.The Gang of Seven‚Äôs decision to quit will feed into the narrative that he is a Marxist mediocrity, whose toxic spell at the helm since  has not only dragged his party to the lunatic fringe but has also allowed vicious anti-Semitism and intolerance to flourish.The seven splitters made precisely those charges yesterday, using language that¬† will be gleefully exploited by Labour‚Äôs opponents.Luciana Berger, the MP for Liverpool Wavertree who has endured death threats and deselection attempts from socialist zealots, said she would be ‚Äúsickened and ashamed to remain in the Labour Party‚Äù because of the¬† ‚Äúculture of bullying, bigotry and intimidation‚Äù.Equally powerful was Chris Leslie,¬† the Nottingham East MP, who argued that Labour had been ‚Äúhijacked by the machine politics of the hard Left‚Äù, peddling ‚Äúabuse and hatred‚Äù.Labour‚Äôs turmoil follows the battering that Corbyn received in a new book by investigative journalist Tom Bower.With a wealth of shocking details, it exposes the full scale of the Labour leader‚Äôs dreary left-wing fanaticism, his links to anti-Semitism, his anti-British instincts and his low intellectual calibre.As the book graphically demonstrates, never was there any politician less fitted for the premiership.Given the y charge sheet against Corbyn, it is amazing that the party split did not happen earlier. But the moderates hung on in the forlorn hope that Corbyn might change or that Labour might move back towards the centre ground.There was never any chance of that.Corbyn and his dogmatic followers are not interested in compromise or debate ‚Äî only in enforcement of their warped ideology.¬† They have turned what was once a broad church into a narrow personality cult.In fact, many Corbynites, like a kind of Trotskyite Taliban, welcome the split because they see it as an opportunity to rid the socialist creed of impurities.‚ÄúThough cowards flinch and traitors sneer, we‚Äôll keep the Red Flag flying here,‚Äù screeched the infantile Young Labour movement.Yet the charge of cowardice is an absurd one to make at the splitters.It took courage to quit. Most of them had relatively safe Labour seats. Yet they have put their political careers and livelihoods at risk in protest at Corbyn.In addition, they will be forced to endure a barrage of abuse from party members, since Labour is a profoundly tribal movement, where betrayal is regarded as the darkest sin of all.But this will only be the start of a major rebellion against Corbyn.To the Gang of Seven can be added three other moderate former Labour MPs who already sit as Independents, namely Frank Field, Ivan Lewis and John Woodcock, who describes Corbyn as ‚Äúa clear risk to national security‚Äù.Public interest in the new group is strong. By early yesterday evening they had gained , followers on Twitter.And more Labour MPs are likely to resign, emboldened by the Gang Of Seven.¬† It should be remembered that in  no fewer than  Labour MPs ‚Äî  per cent of the parliamentary party ‚Äî openly declared their lack of confidence in Corbyn‚Äôs leadership.Tellingly, Tom Watson, the Deputy Leader, said in a bitter swipe at Corbyn yesterday that he ‚Äúno longer recognised‚Äù his own party and merely condemned the defections as ‚Äúpremature‚Äù.Even with its modest beginnings, the Independent Group launch represents the biggest split in British politics since the formation of the SDP in , when Labour was lurching to the Left under Michael Foot. But the parallel with the SDP also highlights the weakness of the new group.The SDP was headed by the big figures of Roy Jenkins, David Owen and Shirley Williams, all experienced Cabinet Ministers and potential premiers.There is no one remotely of that stature among the new Independents.Their most high-profile member, Umunna, briefly ran for the Labour leadership in  but withdrew at the first whf of media scrutiny.Nor does the Independent Group have a coherent set of policies beyond being anti-Corbyn and pro-EU.In contrast, the SDP had a clear stance in favour of Britain‚Äôs nuclear deterrent, Common Market membership and the market economy.The splitters‚Äô claim to be standing up for democracy is also weakened by their reluctance to accept the result of the  EU referendum, the greatest democratic exercise in British political history. Indeed, in their Remoaner posturing, there is an unpleasant air of the narrow, metropolitan progressive elite about their operation so far.Nevertheless,they help to prevent the election of Corbyn, they will do a service to British politics, just as the SDP helped to halt the advance of Foot almost  years ago. If the new Independent Group is really to reshape the British political landscape, it will have to be far more than just a narrow, elitist breakaway from Labour.A burst of anti-Corbyn hype is not enough. To become an authentic third force that dominates the centre, it will have to attract MPs from other parties.That means taking over the increasingly moribund Lib Dems, now led by the ineffectual Sir Vince Cable.More importantly, it¬†¬† requires winning over Left-inclined Tories and anti-Brexit MPs such as the noisy Anna Soubry and the former GP Sarah Wollaston.Gaining Conservative support was precisely what the SDP failed to do, ultimately dooming it to failure. Just one Tory MP, Christopher Brocklebank-Fowler, became a Social Democrat.Gang of Seven member Gavin Shuker said that Labour had ‚Äúturned its back on the British public‚Äù.He is absolutely right ‚Äî which is¬† why Corbyn‚Äôs mob must not be allowed near power.¬†Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: universal credit benefit boost poverty amber rudd
story: Amber Rudd hailed a fresh report which said the new benefits system will help pull hundreds of thousands out of poverty in future, but vowed to do more to make it work.New research from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation showed that the system had the potential to help desperate Brits, taking , working families out of poverty.They think that .million working families are set to see their incomes increase by an average of ¬£, a year on the new system.Since more money was pumped into the scheme in last years budget - including a ¬£ hike to the amount people can work without getting their benefits slashed - there will be more winners.The Work and Pensions boss said the research showed¬†that the new system can help parents out of poverty - None were in school.During dawn raids on  fortied properties in Tandarei, officers found a shocking cache of weapons, including AKs, powerful hunting rles, knives, pistols and ammunition, along with gold bullion and enormous bundles of cash containing hundreds of thousands of pounds.There were also hundreds of fake British passports, birth certicates and forged Home Office documents for children, which allowed them to fly their victims to Britain with impunity.In the face of such damning evidence, it is surprising to say the least that the case against them has been dropped, their assets ed - meaning for the poor children of Tandarei, it is business as usual.Retired British Superintendent Bernie Gravett says: ‚ÄúThey are proper gangsters. These are not just a few people making a few bob, this is an international organised crime ring - one of the largest.‚ÄúWe recovered hundreds of thousands of British pounds, euros, dollars, Romanian lei, . kilograms of gold, AKs, and all of these guys had huge houses, BMWs and Audis.‚ÄùBernie‚Äôs role in bringing the case to court was pivotal and resulted in a groundbreaking change in the law after he presented a case to the European Parliament in , which meant children could be classed as being trafficked to beg and steal.Before this, trafficking only applied to sexual exploitation, forced labour and organ harvesting.Today, all his hard work is hanging by a thread and with the evidence pointing towards corruption.‚ÄúThese guys have millions and we knew at the outset this was a risk,‚Äù he says.For eight years, the criminal case has dragged on.¬†It was postponed during an astonishing  dferent hearings.Over the years, the first prosecutor was changed at the request of the UK over complaints of lack of co-operation and the second prosecutor chose not to use any of the evidence collected in Britain which showed children found in squalid conditions, their fake passports, bruised faces and countless testimonies of their exploitation.And in a telling sign of how things would turn out, prosecutors downgraded the legal status of the children from ‚Äòvictims‚Äô to ‚Äòwitnesses‚Äô.In the final hearing at Harghita Court on February , the judge, at the request of the prosecutor, changed the charges from trafficking in human beings and transnational organised crime to money laundering.This meant the defendants, who have been on bail other than the first  months following their arrest, were all immediately acquitted because of the statute of limitation for this lesser charge.One of the defendants, leader Constantin Radu, who is in his s and is nicknamed ‚ÄòTiti the Burglar‚Äô, is estimated to have amassed millions through his criminal enterprise.Incidentally, his son Adrian Radu and daughter-in-law, Claudia, were jailed in England in  for  months and six months respectively in a benefits fraud case that cost the UK taxpayer ¬£,.Romania‚Äôs Judicial Inspectorate says it will investigate how this happened, but for now, not one person in Tandarei has faced justice in the Romanian courts.Meanwhile, many of the  child victims are missing.There is mounting anger over what has happened, with a spokesman for the NSPCC saying: ‚ÄúTrafficking is a form of child abuse and these desperately vulnerable children need our help, and perpetrators tracked down and brought to justice.‚ÄúNo child should be subjected to ruthless treatment from such gangs which are organised and do not care about the safety of vulnerable children. It is a vile trade and children need to be protected from these predators.‚ÄùAnd this week,  international and Romanian NGOs and human rights groups signed a letter calling for the case to be reopened ‚Äúto make Romania responsible for its specic obligations under the international conventions against organised crime and human trafficking that it is part of.‚ÄùThe letter, sent to around a dozen organisations including the UN, the Vatican, Parliament and the Council of Europe, is headlined: ‚ÄúCall to action‚Ä¶Organised criminals let off in Romania! Organised crime wins as the Romanian Justice System lets off a network of human traffickers the UK and Romanian police were funded to entrap.‚ÄùIt continues: ‚ÄúThe UK authorities estimated that for each exploited child the network‚Äôs profit was ¬£, per year. Victims identied in UK were exploited for at least two years, with the youngest being only a few months old.‚ÄúBased on these facts and many other similar cases that are not effectively handled by the Romanian authorities.‚ÄùHuman trafficking expert Silvia Tabusca, from the European Centre for Legal Education and Research, helped organise the letter with Bernie because of her ‚Äúshock and disappointment‚Äù with the way the case has been handled.‚ÄúThe network is still working, everyone knows it,‚Äù she says.‚ÄúMany of the victims are missing now, we couldn‚Äôt identy any of them.‚ÄúWe have a huge amount of evidence from the UK. We have videos, testimonials, we have a lot that was not used by the prosecutor and the court.‚ÄùShe explains how many of the child victims were sent back to Romania with no protection, which meant they changed the statements given to British Police as they no longer felt in a safe position to tell the truth.She adds: ‚ÄúWhen the victims were repatriated in Romania they had no protection at all, so they were placed back in their families and when the victims were heard again by the prosecutor, they changed their testimonials.‚ÄúBack in Romania, many of the trafficked children reversed their UK statements, and claimed they were well looked after rather than victims of abuse. Evidence from the UK of empty fridges and poor living conditions suggested neglect.‚ÄúI‚Äôve never understood why the prosecutor took into consideration the second testimonial of the victims when the British police had a specic procedure to ensure the testimonials taken in the UK can be used in the courts in Romania.‚ÄùTragically for the town‚Äôs children, the exploitation continues, with Germany being the new favoured destination for trafficked minors, although Britain remains a hot-spot.Meanwhile, Romania is classed as the main country of origin for all trafficked people, according to Europol.Back in Tandarei, town hall inspector Constantin Vladila, says the Roma gypsy gangsters have become very rich thanks to the money they receive from their crimes.‚ÄúWith the money they receive abroad they build these villas,‚Äù he says. They show off their Gucci shoes and gold necklaces.‚ÄùYet not only are they rich, these are hardened, weaponised and ruthless criminals who are not afraid to use violence to exert their iron grip on the town, which is permeated by a culture of fear.The gangs have people watching, called ‚Äúlookers‚Äù on street corners, making sure everyone keeps in line and during one of the raids on the villas, police found a chair bolted to the floor with ankle and wrist straps, which chillingly shows the fate of anyone who doesn‚Äôt.As one Tandarei political insider, who was afraid to be named for fear of his reprisals, says: ‚ÄúThe gangs even speak proudly about what theyre doing abroad. Here they have the law in their hands.‚ÄùOn the snow-covered streets of Tandarei, locals keep their heads down and refuse to speak or tell their names when approached. Nor will they answer questions as to what is happening to the town‚Äôs children.But with the threat of violence looming almost as large as the monstrous mansions paid for by the proceeds of such evil, it is little wonder why.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lord saatchi says google facebook owes you money
story: When you use your phone today, your head is served up on a plate.Advertisers make a second-by-second market in you. Your mind is bought and sold by their computer programs ‚Äî with no human intervention required.You are the digital content they auction off for sale to the highest bidder. Billions of pounds pass before your eyes every day. But you don‚Äôt see a penny of it.It‚Äôs unfair. Never has so much been taken from so many by so few.So it is time to have a big redistribution of digital wealth.Google shareholders and Facebook boss Mark ¬≠Zuckerberg are now worth .TRILLION. How much are you worth Remember, your mind is  per cent of the revenue of these corporations. So it is only right to demand your share.The British people, who set the world an example in waging a revolutionary war against feudal slavery, now find themselves in the latest stage of wage-slavery, working for the benefit of these wealthy companies and ¬≠billionaires.The richest and strongest profit and grab most, while the weakest are utterly robbed, tormented, crushed and strangled.The tech multi-billionaires are, perhaps, some of the richest of all, and geographically the most secure.They have profited more than all the rest from their unholy alliance with weak national governments, who say their own parliaments and laws are too small to control or regulate these giant global corporations.Call it what it is ‚Äî collusion, crony capitalism. The big companies and big government are hand in hand.The House of Commons‚Äô Digital Select Committee this week called the tech giants ‚Äúdigital gangsters‚Äù.But even a good Saatchi alumnus like Damian Collins ‚Äî the committee‚Äôs distinguished chairman ‚Äî concedes the politicians have no power over these companies.Instead, it‚Äôs time for the people ‚Äî the customers who keep the tech companies afloat ‚Äî to take a stand.It is unfair that these few companies are so rich, and the many people are so poor.So, I say: Let us march! We are  per cent on the side of the heroes. They are  per cent on the side of the villains. Black and white. No compromise.When the tech companies say: ‚ÄúWe agree in principle‚Äù, it means they will do nothing in practice.They say fair exchange is no robbery. You provide them with all your personal details ‚Äî your age, gender, every friend, every photo you send, every film you watch, every app you download, every website you visit, every message, every item you buy, everywhere you go and where you are now ‚Äî and inthey give you the wonders of the internet world.And as your bonus, they only send you ‚Äúpersonalised‚Äù ads. Soyou want a new shampoo they don‚Äôt ‚Äúserve‚Äù you a dishwasher.They are for the haves who hold power. We are for the have-nots.This is not a question of ‚Äúprivacy‚Äù. Or ‚Äúharmful material‚Äù. Or ‚Äúelection interference‚Äù.This is a question of money.They have too much. We have too little. So we will make what seems highly improbable in fact happen.Every time Google or Facebook sell you to an advertiser, you should get paid for the privilege. Fair shares for all. The technology exists to make this possible.¬†YouTube already pays people for the number of times their uploaded data is viewed.These companies only care about the millions of users they can sell to advertisers.What was your name again  Here is your chance to get your own back. A business model that says I get  per cent and you get  per cent is not going to last.The tech giants should remember what all Prime Ministers and Presidents usually learn too late.We the people have all the power. It‚Äôs best not to push us to use it.I say we need a popular uprising. A people‚Äôs revolution. Agitate! Create disenchantment! Build discontent!Join me and say: Start spreading the news. I say we want control. Ownership of our own minds.The new tech billionaires once used to dream of changing the world. Now they‚Äôve got the whole world, they don‚Äôt want to let it go.They used to say: Set sail for the end of the rainbow.But now they say: Don‚Äôt rock the boat. They are turning into exactly the type of people they once condemned.The time has come to call a halt to their complacency and self-satisfaction. Will this cost them money  Yes, peanuts.But whatever it costs, it will be less than having the money dragged out of them.A society without ownership is one in which inequality and resentment flourish.Honour, common sense and the interest of the country require that all free British men and women, wherever they be, now fight for control of their own minds.We will feel more responsible for our own lives.And everyone will agree that this makes everything much fairer and that the people have gained more dignity and self-respect.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lord levy jeremy corbyn plot labour party

title: weather pink fog uk today
story: Locals were tickled pink as the rosy colour blanketed the sky in regions across the South West of England.One excited local snapped a photo showing the pink fog in Shropshire while others spotted the rare phenomenon in Weston-Super-Mare, Somerset.Met Office spokesperson Graham Madge explained the stunning sight was similar to that of a sunset or a sunrise but filtered through the fog.He said: When the sunlight comes through lots of layers, it filters out the blue and scatters it, leaving the red light to come through.Its effectively a sunrise filtered through the atmosphere and through the fog, giving it that pinkish hue.Mr Madge added that the spectacular sight would have likely been seen by a lucky few.He explained: You would have needed to be in the right place at the right time.It will depend on the local conditions, and those conditions were optimal for a few lucky people to have witnessed it.One stunned Brit took to social media to share a photo of a trees outline against the unusual hue, saying: This morning we have pink fog... pink  What the...Another added: Everyone just loves a pink sky.But the weather hasnt been all rosy for Brits this morning.The heavy fog caused delays at most airports around London, sparking warnings for passengers to check their flights.The delays come after the Met Office released a severe weather warning¬†for fog this morning across the East Midlands, Suffolk, South East and South West.And the cloudy weather hasnt only affected flights - travellers closer to the ground are also facing problems.Luckily, Brits can look forward to the fog clearing today to bring warmer weather - about C hotter than average for this time of year.Scotlands warm¬†weather¬†already broke records yesterday with temperatures in Aboyne reaching .C, overtaking the previous .C high set in Aberdeen in .Tropical air has been blown , miles from the Caribbean to Scotland, with the highs hotter than Alexandria in Egypt, where the mercury reached C.

title: bbc sheffield fly past dan walker tears flying fortress
story: Pensioner Tony Foulds broke down in tears as ten airmen who died saving his le  years ago by crashing their plane were honoured with the flypast.Tony Foulds, , was just a boy when he saw the B- Flying Fortress, nicknamed Mi Amigo, crash at Endclfe Park, Sheffield, on February  .Mr Foulds had a chance meeting with BBCs Dan Walker which prompted a social media campaign to commemorate the men on the th anniversary of the tragic accident.The presenter watched the flypast live from Tanzania and tweeted: Thousands of people expected in Endclfe Park today for the Mi Amigo flypast. There will be at least  more watching from Tanzania too.The hashtag #TONYGOTAFLYPAST was also trending on Twitter.Speaking from Tanzania,¬†Dan¬†Walker¬†told Mr Foulds: The last six weeks have been remarkable from my point of view.From you and I meeting on a dog walk in the park in the first week of January to me asking how you were - thats how it all started - you telling me this unbelievable story and saying youd love a flypast for the th anniversary, and here we are now.Tony, its always been about those  men who you think saved your le  years ago.Mr Foulds responded: Well I know they saved my le, I didnt just think it.If it hadnt have been for them, I wouldnt be here with my family.In the days before the flypast, Mr Foulds was also able to meet the families of the airmen that lost their lives as the plane ed from a bombing raid  years ago.The pensioner described them as lovely, lovely people.He believes that the pilot had deliberately steered away from him and his friends, and has dedicated decades of his le to looking after a memorial to the men at the park.The horror crash took place on February ,  when ten airmen in a US bomber died.The B- was ing from a raid in Denmark when it flew hundreds of miles off course.The pilot went to land in Endclfe Park in Sheffield, but pulled up when he saw Tony, then eight, and pals playing football. The bomber then crashed into a hill.¬†Earlier today, thousands of people gathered in the park to see Mr Foulds, who has tended to the memorial six days a week and got his son to fill in whenever he has been away, watch the planes, including F-E Strike Eagles from the USAF and a Typhoon from the RAF, fly over.Mr Foulds said: If it hadnt been for them, I wouldnt be here with my family.Its more than bravery, what they did.They saved me, and I mean saved me.The pensioner, broke down in tears after the names of the dead men were read out at the memorial.In the days before the flypast, Mr Foulds was also able to meet the families of the airmen that lost their lives as the plane ed from a bombing raid  years ago.The pensioner described them as lovely, lovely people.Overcome by emotion, Mr Foulds wiped away tears as he reacted to the flypast.He said: Thank you, I cant believe all this. This is unbelievable to me.A crowd of thousands of people in Endclfe Park, Sheffield, cheered following the flypast on Friday morning.A clear day meant that the assembled audience had a good view of the planes flying over.Wreaths have been laid at the graves of three American airmen who died when their plane crashed over Sheffield in .Three of the  crew of the B- Flying Fortress, Mi Amigo, are interred at Cambridge American Cemetery.The seven other crew members who died have been repatriated.The headstones of Staff Sergeant Harry W Estabrooks, Sergeant Maurice D Robbins and Sergeant Charles H Tuttle were dressed on Friday with sand from Omaha Beach in Normandy, France.An American and British flag was positioned by each of the three graves, along with a photograph of each crew member.Wreaths were laid at each grave simultaneously as a memorial flypast soared over Endclfe Park in Sheffield.The ceremony was attended by local Royal British Legion members, who had the wreaths specially made after they were contacted by a branch in Sheffield.Kevin Swann, secretary of the Sawston and Pampisford branch in Cambridgeshire, said: Its a fitting tribute to the men but its also paid tribute to all who lost their lives and are buried on this site, and to the . million American service personnel that were over in this country during the Second World War.Mr Foulds waved as the planes started to fly over, making his dream come true some  years after the crash.Shortly before the flypast started, he said: This is not for me, its for them - my lads.Theyre family, they are family to me.

title: ecuador earthquake today 77 magnitude ambato
story: The quake, initially measured as magnitude . but now scaled down to ., struck at the border with Peru.Tremors were felt in both countries and also parts of Colombia, according to reports.The United States Geological Survey said the quake happened at . kilometerssoutheast of the town of Palora, in the Morona Santiago province.It struck at a depth of  kilometers .Perus official geophysics institute said it registered two aftershocks of . and . magnitude in the  minutes that followed the first tremor.One resident in Cuenca, Ecuador,  miles from the epicentre, described the quake as very strong, while a second resident in the same city reported experiencing a good  second shake, according to witness statements on the European-Mediterranean Seismological Centre website.Video footage and photos of the devastation have appeared on social media, with one woman pictured with her jacket over her head as she runs for cover.People have also been pictured running from buildings during the quake.One woman posted online: Strong rattling of our windows woke us up. Continued for quite some time. Outside, trees and power lines were swaying. Our dog was scared.Another person described the quake as a wake-up call in a tweet showing a video of their chandelier swinging back and forth.Emergency services are helping with evacuations in areas worst hit by the earthquake, which happened around kmeast-southeast of Ambato, Ecuador.No tsunami warning has been issued but aftershocks are still expected.Miraculously, there has been no reports of serious injuries.Ecuadors President Lenin Moreno said on his official Twitter account that preliminary reports of the quakes near Macasdont show major damage.The quakes, he wrote, were felt all over the country.

title: john mcdonnell israel labour shamima begum
story: The revelation comes despite Labour saying ISIS teen Shamima Begum should be allowed back to Britain.Mr Corbyn said the -year-old jihadist should be given support and not have her citizenship revoked.But in , Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell suggested British citizens in the Israeli military should be at risk of having their passports stripped.He wrote to Theresa May, then the Home Secretary, and asked her to take action against UK-Israeli dual nationals.Mr McDonnell suggested they may have been implicated in war crimes related to the Israeli Defence Forces campaigns in Gaza.He said: I am aware of the Government‚Äôs policy of detaining and prosecuting those British citizens travelling to fight in the current Middle East conflicts.Will you be warning any British citizens considering engagement with the IDF that, in line with established British Government practice , such engagement may put their British citizenship in jeopardy Given the seriousness of the current situation in Gaza and the apparent escalation of the Israeli attacks on Palestinians, I urge you to address these questions promptly so that any British citizen currently participating or planning to participate in these attacks is warned of the potential consequences and thus may be deterred from acting in this way.The letter, revealed by the Guido Fawkes blog, was deleted from Mr McDonnells website some time after he became Shadow Chancellor.A Labour spokesman said: This was at the height of the barbaric bombing and attacks on Gaza when hundreds of Palestinian men, women and children were being killed.This is a simple statement of law and standard practice by the government aimed at deterring and pointing out the risks involved in British citizens joining any foreign conflict. For those holding joint citizenship it does not entail making them stateless.Yesterday Mr Corbyn sparked anger by backing Begums right toto the UK despite fleeing four years ago to join ISIS.He said: She was born in Britain, she has that right to remain in Britain and obviously a lot of questions she has to answer but also some support that she needs.The Labour boss was accused of siding with Britains enemies after his controversial intervention.

title: barristers given advice on what to do if they are bullied by judges
story: The guide says only a handful of top justices browbeat the lawyers.But their targets ‚Äî who train for at least five years ‚Äî can feel helpless.The Bar Council is now looking at setting up a whistleblower hotline.The guidance, sent to all barristers in England and Wales, says: ‚ÄúBullying of barristers is always unacceptable.‚ÄúWhen bullying by judges occurs it presents additional challenges.‚ÄúThose who are a target may feel unable, or particularly reluctant, to do anything about it, even though the impact may be particularly acute.‚ÄúAt the same time, judges have an important independent constitutional status and are removable from office only for good reason.‚ÄùIt adds: ‚ÄúThe Bar Council recognises the right approach to dealing with judicial bullying presents dficulties and complications that do not apply in other contexts.‚ÄùThe guide tells¬† briefs to keep notes and ask for advice ‚Äî but says the worst incidents should be reported.Council boss Richard Atkins QC adds that only a few¬† judges ‚Äúengage in bullying‚Äù but it must never be excused.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit backstop plan theresa may eu irish border vote
story: The PM spoke at the Northern Irish border earlier this month. Heres the latest on the tricky talking point.The backstop plan is essentially a safety netthere is no Brexit trade deal.It would avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.Also, it would ensure that no tarfs, quotas, rules of origin or customs processes would be applied to UK-EU trade.But it is unclearthe UK would be able to strike free trade agreements with other countries while the backstop endured.And it is feared the UK would end up being trapped in the customs union. The PM is now hoping to negotiate a way around this.On January  the Prime Minister succeeded in a parliamentary vote which united her party behind a plan to rewrite the deal to address concerns about the Irish backstop.In dramatic scenes, Tory and rebel Labour MPs voted by a margin of  to  to back a plan - the Brady amendment - which requires the PM to replace the Agreements controversial backstop with alternative arrangements to keep the Irish border open after Brexit.But senior figures in Brussels, Berlin, Paris and Dublin resisted the demand from May as the clock ticks down to the UKs departure from the European Union on March .Speaking in Belfast yesterday, the PM vowed to back a joint bid for the  World Cup by all the countries of the British Isles.And she pledged that after Brexit, the UK will have a¬†closer relationship with Ireland¬†than with any other European country.Mrs May also risked angering her MPs by suggesting she might not ditch the backstop after all.In a speech aimed squarely at winning goodwill from Dublin, the PM said: Our relationship with Ireland is deeper than our relationship with any of the other . It is uniquely rooted in ties of family, history and geography.The recent past has been a moment of reflection in the UK and Ireland as we have commemorated the centenary of a series of key events in our shared history.Today those ties of family and friendship between our countries are more important than they have ever been.And I believe there is a yearning in the hearts of all the peoples of these islands for a close and trusting relationship between all of us, and an absolute horror that we should take even a single step backwards in the progress we have collectively achieved.She proposed¬†annual meetings between the British and Irish governments¬†after Brexit to ensure the two countries work closely together.She promised to lobby Mrs May on the issue when they hold talks in Belfast on February .She said: We will be reiterating our opposition to the current backstop. And the fact that Parliament has now backed that position means that she has a clear mandate to go back to Brussels.The current backstop is toxic to those of us living in Northern Ireland, and indeed for unionists right across the United Kingdom, because it would cause the break-up of the United Kingdom into the medium and longer term.May also had dinner with Taoiseach Leo Varadkar after her meeting in Brussels to try and break the deadlock in negotiations.Attorney General Geoffrey Cox will hold talks in the Irish capital with his Irish counterpart, Seamus Woulfe.Cox has been leading work within Whitehall on providing either a time limit on the backstop or giving the UK an exit mechanism from it.Both proposals have received a dusty response from Dublin, which insists the backstop cannot be time limitedit is to provide an effective insurance policy against theof a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit news latest tory mps theresa may deal
story: Leaders of a -strong centrist group have told Mrs May she faces a mass rebellionshe doesnt get her Brexit deal over the line within days.They are set to join a Remainer plot to delay Britains exit from the EU in order to rule out a No Deal outcome.Defeat would be a huge blow for Mrs May - who needs to keep No Deal on the table in order to boost her leverage in talks with the EU.The Government wants to bring the Brexit deal back to the Commons next week.If they dont, MPs will have a chance to vote on what the next steps should be instead.Last night Simon Hart and Andrew Percy, leaders of the -strong Brexit Delivery Group which has so far been loyal to Mrs May, wrote to her to warn her plan is in danger.They said: Numerous members of our group have alerted us to their intentionto get behind amendments that are planned in the name of Oliver Letwin and others and which will have the twin effect of taking No Deal off the table and delaying Brexit.Today Mr Percy told the BBC: Dozens of colleagues have made clear to me that they would want to vote to prevent a hard No Deal Brexit.A lot of colleagues have become very frustrated, a lot of colleagues have compromised.He blamed the pro-Brexit European Research Group for refusing to back the PMs deal in the previous meaningful vote.The rebels could include as many as two dozen ministers and even members of the Cabinet.But from the other side the ERG are warning Mrs May she faces a furious backlashshe allows No Deal to be blocked.The Brexiteers could end up blocking all Government legislation in protest at any delay to our departure.

title: labour brexit second referendum independent group
story: Party bosses are considering backing a Commons motion which would trigger a so-called peoples vote on whether to stay in the EU.It comes as pro-Remain MPs warn Mr Corbyn theyll walk out and join the Independent Grouphe doesnt endorse a second referendum, that could sabotage Brexit.Dozens of Labour MPs are reportedly considering resigning over Corbyns approach to Brexit.Theyve told the party leader they will join up with the  members of the Independent Group - who are hugely pro-Europe - unless he gets behind a referendum.Official party policy is to push for a General Election and a new Brexit deal which keeps Britain in the customs union - butthat fails, Labour is open to all options.John McDonnell, Mr Corbyns right-hand man, today hinted the leader is close to backing a referendum.He told the Evening Standard: On the people‚Äôs vote, we‚Äôve kept it on the table and we‚Äôre moving towards that.Next week two Labour backbenchers plan to push an amendment which would approve Mrs Mays Brexit deal but also put it to a public vote.Mr McDonnell said the motion drawn up by Peter Kyle and Phil Wilson could be a solution.It would give voters a choice between staying in the EU, or leaving on the terms proposed by the PM.Mrs May will fiercely resist any moves towards a second referendum - and it could be scuppered by Labour MPs from pro-Leave seats.The new Independent Group is widely seen as an anti-Brexit movement - with the main policy connecting its  MPs being a second referendum.Joan Ryan is accused of wrongly accessing Labours computer systems to try and contact party members after she resigned.Party bosses have now reported her to the Information Commissioners Office for a full investigation.Ms Ryan, who quit on Tuesday night to join the Independent Group, denies any wrongdoing.She told the : Neither I nor my office have accessed or used any Labour party data since I resigned the Labour whip and my membership of the Labour party.A Labour spokesman said: The Labour party became aware of attempts to access personal data held on the party‚Äôs systems for unauthorised use.Personal data the party holds about iniduals is protected by law, under the GDPR and Data Protection Act .Today Vince Cable of the Europhile Lib Dems suggested forming an electoral pact with the group.He suggested his party wouldnt stand candidates against the Independent Group in a future by-election.Ian Austin this morning became the ninth Labour MP to quit in protest against Mr Corbyn - but he wont join the Independent Group because he disagrees with their stance on Brexit.
