title: independent group not what you
story: NewsopinionThe Independent Group is not what you think it isIts not a party, its not centrist and its not the solutionShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsopinion"Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIn a shared nightmare no-one can wake up from, the idea of some centrist peace and quiet is appealing. Thats why The Independent Group is polling in third place just  days after it launched. For those fundamentalists who insist dreamland is the best place to stay, its also appealing to blame the TIGgers for an impending lack of unicorns. But TIG is not the answer to our problems. Oh, its great for providing an escape route to all those who like to complain but have no idea what to do. If youre a Corbynista, Brexit headbanger or raging anti-Semite, the appearance of traitors proves all your conspiracy theories true: it was definitely THEIR fault. And for the average voter - the one whos seen a referendum turn to dust while sleep-deprived toddlers bitchslap each other around Westminster like a kindergarten whose teacher has just stepped outside for three years - it looks a lot like the grown-ups have arrived, offering a coherent, mature, alternative to extremist chaos. Its indisputable TIGs appearance was an attention-grabbing thwack of the Parliamentary blackboard. Unfortunately, its  members have not got a Scooby Doo what to do next. They have told the class to shut up and listen. But they dont know what to say.  If you look at the voting records of its members, TIG agrees wholeheartedly with itself that Britain needed austerity as well as spending. It wants to tax the rich more and less, and wants gays to have both more and fewer rights. It wants more private healthcare and to protect the NHS, to lower and raise welfare benefits, and it simultaneously supports and rejects university tuition fees, mass surveillance, and immigration controls. Its only centristyou add all that up and ide it by the Lib Dems. There are just two topics its members seem to agree on - Remaining, and the smoking ban. Thats not enough common ground to stand on for more than  minutes, never mind a -year Parliamentary term. If their unity couldnt survive a conversation in the pub, what can they achieve  Last month a string of crunch votes on Brexit produced majorities of between just  and  votes. The Brady Amendment which threw Theresa May a leline passed with just , putting our  TIGgers in a strong position to sway Brexit. If they combine with the  Lib Dems and  Scots nationalists - never mind potentially hundreds of dissenters in the main parties - they might command a majority to bring down Brexit, the government, or both. So its a damned shame theyve said they wont.  Well, *they* havent - one of the TIGgers, Gavin Shuker, has said he would prop up the government infor a soft Brexit and second referendum. And theres the problem writ large: theyre independent of each other, as well. They have chosen not to pay the pound Electoral Commission fee to register a new party. Theyve instead rented a room above a Spoons and paid pound to register at Companies House as a limited company, which doesnt exactly look like theyre aiming for Downing Street. Chuka Umunna, who is closest to being the leader the TIGgers dont have, says British politics is broken and urged those from other parties to join them. But when put on the spot hes been unable to name a single current Labour policy he disagrees with, or clearly explain what, exactly, TIG wants. The defection press conferences were aimed not at the electorate but their parties - the equivalent of hurling abuse over your shoulder before slamming the door on your way out. None of it, so far, has included an idea about a better or dferent party.  That hasnt stopped anyone referring to the non-party as a party. It hasnt stopped % of the electorate deciding to vote for the non-electable non-party with no policies. Not knowing quite what they stand for hasnt stopped their enemies decrying what they stand for. And the fact they cant agree on how to deal with % of our problems hasnt stopped any of us hoping they can, nevertheless, fix them. They are the first MPs to recognise and reflect the fact that most British people want Labours economic policies - tax the rich, spend on services, regulate the banks - AND a Tory brake on social change - immigration controls, crime crackdowns, and let Shamima Begum rot . The will of the people is clear, and utterly incomprehensible. So you can hardly blame TIG for incoherent babbling, because the rest of us are frankly no better. Chuka calls them a movement, but it doesnt move us any further on and has yet to find the messiah it needs to drive any meaningful change. Instead, the TIGgers have each picked an enemy of reason - Brexit, anti-Semitism, entryism, tribal politics, Jacob Rees-Mogg - and vowed to smash it.  Any tiger with a spring in its tail would get publicity and public support but  of them, winding up the racists and safe-spacers alike, can expect exactly the degree of hero-worship theyre getting. Thats why theyre not a party. And its why they dont want by-elections. Their aim is not to be a government-in-waiting, but to break the extremist grip which is choking the le out of both main parties. It is worth noting that  by-elections would force these MPs to absent themselves from Parliament at just the point that they could wreak the most havoc on Brexit and those shouting loudest for by-elections are very Brexity. But when May and Corbyns puppeteers have their strings cut, Brexit is delayed or trashed and were looking for new leaders in the wasteland on the other side of March , what is right, and what will be left  TIG is not the answer. It is posing a question those on all sides know must be asked - where do we go next   The TIGgers do not know. They just like to bounce - bounce the voters out of despair, the main parties out of entrail-gnawing complacency. They have no plan for what to do next, because one TIGger couldnt agree with himself, never mind  more. They are not your great, centrist, hope. They are  wrecking balls, hoping to clear the decks for something . That something has yet to manest, and the thing that will decide whether it is populist or popular will depend largely what sort of messiah we get. The first of those two options that gets a charismatic and inspiring leader will be the one to turn our heads. Remember: TIGgers dont roar. Enjoy the bouncing, and lets just hope that when the king of the jungle turns up, its Mufasa and not Scar.

The problem hits council and social housing tenants who pay rent once a week.Many will make  rent payments in   because the financial year has  Mondays. Yet they are due the same amount of Universal Credit asthey paid  weeks, because the six-in-one benefit is calculated dferently.DWP officials at first insisted there are no plans to change the system because it would be too complicated. But now, in a newsletter to landlords, the DWP has said: We are currently considering whether this formulation around weekly rents, and potentially other weekly amounts in theUCcalculation, should be amended.   A DWP spokesman confirmed: ‚ÄúWhile our policy has not changed, we continue to listen to feedback about Universal Credit and work with claimants and landlords to review how the system is working.‚ÄùThe problem, raised by the NHF and first reported by Inside Housing, is expected to affect Universal Credit claimants who pay weekly rent once every six years.The NHF says that because UC is paid monthly, it is calculated using a formula that effectively takes  of a claimants weekly rent payments and ides the total by . But there are  weeks plus one day in each year. That means every six years or so, a tenant has to make  rent payments, not . The DWP admitted in its newsletter: The Department has recognised that there is [an] issue with regards to the way the calculation in the Universal Credit regulations converts a weekly liability into a monthly allowance. The conversion is achieved by multiplying the weekly rent by  and then iding by . This effectively means one day‚Äôs rent a yearare not covered byUC. title: alesha macphail everything know smirking
story: NewsAlesha MacPhail: Everything we know about smirking child killer Aaron CampbellCampbell, , was finally unmasked as Aleshas killer today, seven months after abducting, raping and murdering the six-year-old on the Isle of Bute, ScotlandShareCommentsBySophie Evans:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video aaron-campbell-made-youtube-video-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTeen Aaron Campbell was today unmasked as Alesha MacPhails killer - seven months after he abducted, raped and murdered the six-year-old. Campbell, , snatched little Alesha from her bed as she visited her dad and grandparents on the Isle of Bute, Scotland, in July last year. He brutally attacked and raped the ft ins youngster before dumping her body in woodland on the scenic and sparsely populated island. Smiley Alesha, who loved watching Peppa Pig and baking cakes, was later found facedown and naked by a member of the public. She had  separate injuries - including catastrophic ones. Campbell, who lived on the island, was yesterday found guilty of her abduction, rape and murder by jurors at Glasgows High Court. And this afternoon, he could be identied for the first time after a judge allowed his name and images of him to be published. Lting a ban on identying the boy, Judge Lord Matthews said: I cant think of a case in recent times that has attracted such revulsion. But who is Campbell and what is his background  Below, we reveal everything we know so far about the monster.  What did Campbell do  Campbell abducted, raped and murdered Alesha, who was staying at the home her dad shared with her grandparents on Bute. The little girl, who was on a three-week summer break, had been put to bed with a Peppa Pig DVD on the night of July , . But the next morning, she was found to have vanished. The High Court later heard Campbell had snatched the girl from the bed where she was sleeping, before inflicting horric injuries on her. He then dumped her body in a woodland area on the island. Alesha was reported missing from her bed at .am on July , with Police Scotland launching a large-scale search to find her. At around am, her naked body was devastatingly found on the grounds of the islands former Kyles Hydropathic Hotel.  A post-mortem found she died from pressure to neck and face. Within days of Aleshas death, Campbell had been arrested and charged. During his trial, the court heard graphic details of Aleshas injuries, with a pathologist saying: Its extremely dficult to give an accurate time of death. When askedthe injuries observed were something he had witnessed before in his years of forensic experience, Dr John Williams replied: No. Yesterday, Lord Matthews told Campbell he had committed some of the wickedest, most evil crimes the High Court had ever heard. Who is Campbell  Campbell was a -year-old cannabis smoker, living on Bute. He had moved to the island with his family as a child, and lived with his mum, dad and younger sister in a traditional stone-built home. He had been born on the mainland, but his family had brought him to the island believing it would give him a secure upbringing. His mum told the Daily Mail: I wanted him to grow up in a safe place, a peaceful environment, and get a good education.  She added that her very normal son was doing an engineering course one day a week and had plans to go to university. Known to pals as a harmless joker with a dark sense of humour, Campbell had started regularly buying cannabis at the age of . He would drink at weekends with friends and had a girlfriend, who is reported to be standing by him despite his brutal crime. He also liked to practice parkour, which involves moving rapidly through areas and jumping from buildings, the Daily Record reports. And he was a fitness fan who enjoyed boxing and lting weights. A video of Campbell, posted on his YouTube channel the year before Aleshas murder, shows him doing carefree flips on a trampoline. He brags he recently went from doing front flip s to front flip .  Had he shown signs of violence  Campbells mum has said he wasnt a violent boy. But reports have claimed he was a ‚Äúserial killercaught on his first murder‚Äù who was obsessed with the horror character Slender Man. He is alleged to have been obsessed with gore and violence. A police source told The Sun: ‚ÄúSlender Man searches were found and it chilled seasoned investigators to the bone. Some of the circumstances between what this character does and what happened to Alesha were carbon copies.‚Äù The teenager was filmed playing violent video games, and officers found evidence he had searched online for the Slender Man. In one clip, he can reportedly be heard shouting stab and shank. In another, he yells: That is Slender Man right there.‚Äù Slender Man is a fictional character that began le as an Internet meme before growing into something much darker.  He has long arms, which he uses to prey on children, and is portrayed as a black and white image on the periphery of photos. Campbell is also alleged to have nearly drowned a dferent young girl at a leisure centre pool years before Aleshas murder. He was just six or seven when he held the youngsters head under the water for so long she feared she would drown, Bute locals claimed. And the killer is said to have slaughtered and skinned cats in his younger teens, apparently burying two feline corpses in his garden. One neighbour also claimed Campbell had become a local nuisance on Bute and was once caught trying to set fire to buildings. None of the stories, including the near-drowning, have been corroborated, but they have been making the rounds on the island. However, his mum insisted to the Mail: He wasn‚Äôt a violent boy. He smoked cannabis, but it‚Äôs re among kids on this island.  What did Campbell tell pals  After Alesha vanished, Campbell chipped in with speculation and rumours about what may have happened on a Snapchat group chat. He even sent a video of himself to pals on the group and said: Found the guy whos done it - something a friend thought was a bad joke. The teenager also sent friends a chilling Facebook message saying he might kill one day for the letime experience, his trial heard. The court was told he exchanged messages about killing with a pal. The female friend asked him the chances of getting away with murder with a good plan, to which he said: Wellit was a gd plan then %. She later messaged: Im glad Im not at the top of your hit list. In response, he was alleged to have said: No one is. The witness agreed these were theoretical exchanges where she brought up the subject of murder and at the time caused her no concern. She said they both had a dark sense of humour. And she agreed the conversation was not serious and just rubbish.  What did Campbell claim about the murder  After police were led to Campbell by his own mum, the monster told ious lies about what he did on the night Alesha vanished. Sickeningly, he even tried to blame Mr MacPhails innocent partner, Toni McLachlan, for the crime and claimed hed had an affair with her. On his trials first day, he lodged a special defence of incrimination, naming Ms McLachlan as the person responsible for the killing. However, jurors heard DNA matching Campbell was pretty well all over Aleshas body and clothes, and he had told police a pack of lies. Giving evidence in court himself, the teenager told the jury hed never do something like that in reference to the attack last summer. He claimed that he never met Alesha MacPhail in person. Askedhe brutalised the girl, he said: Its not me, absolutely not. I would never do something like that.  But when jurors were out of the courtroom, he is said to have been spotted smirking. The teenager, described as an adrenaline junkie, also told the court he and Ms McLachlan had met up and had sex early on July . He claimed he did not want to tell police this as he feared it would get back to Mr MacPhail and he would hurt Ms McLachlan. He also said a claim by Campbell - that Ms McLachlan had taken the condom the two allegedly used on July , gone back to the house where she had been staying with her partner, Alesha and the girls grandparents, abducted the schoolgirl, carried her to the woods, smothered her to death and then planted the accuseds semen inside her - was a preposterous story. story: NewsBeauty blogger who cakes face to hide acne bravely shares make-up free selfiesOffice worker Kara Eden, , who posted the images on Instagram, believes her skin issues began around three years ago when she stopped taking the contraceptive pillShareCommentsByErin Cardf:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news weird-news video blogger-self-conscious-cystic-acne-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A beauty blogger so embarrassed by her cystic acne that she would ‚Äúcake‚Äù herself in make-up has bravely shared au naturel Instagram selfies to reveal her spots.Kara Eden, , believes her skin issues began around three years ago when she stopped taking the contraceptive pill - at first thinking it was a phase and the spots would heal on their own.But the office worker, from Manchester, realised it was cystic acne - the most severe form of the condition which causes large pus-filled pimples.Her confidence was shattered and she would apply full make-up every time she left the house, evenshe was just heading out to the local shop.   In late , after suffering for around  months, Kara ditched her heavy foundation and courageously shared slap-free photos on Instagram, attracting praise and thousands of followers. Kara said: ‚ÄúIt is scary to put myself out there, hitting that send button is a big thing. ‚ÄúI used to edit all my photos, but then I stopped and thought, ‚ÄòNo, you‚Äôre putting this out there for a reason ‚Äì to show your real skin. ‚ÄúOn Instagram especially, everything is so flawless and filtered that I knew there was a gap that needed to be filled for people to embrace their insecurities.‚Äù   Growing up, Kara never had any problems with her skin. But all that changed around three years ago, when she stopped taking the contraceptive pill. She said: ‚ÄúI believe it was down to the imbalanced hormones in my body. I went to the doctor, and was placed on a dferent type of pill, but all that did was mask my symptoms. ‚ÄúAs soon as I stopped taking it, my skin flared up again, even worse than before.‚Äù  At first, Kara thought her skin would settle back down once her body adjusted to the hormonal changes. But after around three months, there were no signs of improvement and so she ed to the doctor and was given antibiotics, which had little effect. So, taking to the internet, she began to read up about cystic acne, and became convinced it was what she had. ‚ÄúIt was a real knock, confidence-wise,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt even leave the house without make-up on. I‚Äôd cake it on evenI was just popping to the shop. I‚Äôd even wear it in the gym, which, looking back, I know is ridiculous.  ‚ÄúThankfully, nobody ever said anything nasty, but I would get stared at, and I could tell what people were thinking.‚Äù Though she initially attempted to treat her acne with topical medication, Kara decided in  to opt for a more natural approach instead. After taking an intolerance test she ordered online, she realised she had been unknowingly eating things that were making her skin worse. So, she overhauled her diet, eliminating dairy and gluten, and cutting right down on sugar.  ‚ÄúAt first, I didn‚Äôt see an immediate effect, so it was hard to stick to,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut after around six weeks, my skin started to improve, and so that spurred me on.‚Äù Also introducing supplements and vitamins to her daily regime, Kara, who only uses natural, organic products as harsh chemicals can have an adverse affect on her skin, ditched medication for good. Keen to use her experiences to help others, she has set up an Instagram where she shares tips and advice, as well as candid photos of her airbrush-free skin. She explained: ‚ÄúI am also a trained make-up artist, so wanted to start a beauty blog, but give it my own inidual spin so started posting a lot about my skin, and DIY healing.  ‚ÄúThe more I shared, the more messages I got, mainly from others in the acne community wanting to knowsomething I was trying had worked. ‚ÄúNow, I have a really loyal following ‚Äì we‚Äôre more like a group of friends.‚Äù By speaking out, Kara, who hailed her boyfriend of three years for supporting her, hopes to encourage others to embrace their insecurities and see past the filtered, edited world of Instagram. And, while she admits that she still feels nervous about uploading her bare-faced selfies, she said that banning herself from editing her perceived imperfections has helped her to accept them.  ‚ÄúThe only way to build confidence is be true to yourself. If you carry on hiding away or editing a part of yourself, you‚Äôll never accept it,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI upload my photos for all those people who don‚Äôt have the confidence, or feel they can‚Äôt among all those flawless Instagram pictures. ‚ÄúI still have peaks and troughs with my skin, but I have learnt not to compare myself to other people.‚Äù Speaking of the link between acne and the contraceptive pill, Dr Zenon Andreou, GP at Zava, Europe‚Äôs largest online doctor, said: The combined contraceptive pill is sometimes prescribed as a way of treating and controlling acne, as it can stabilise fluctuating hormone levels which can lead to skin inflammation, spots and in some cases, acne. Coming off the combined contraceptive pill can cause changes to your skin and its not uncommon for women to experience an acne flare up. If your skin hasn‚Äôt settled down after a month or two of coming off the pill, orthe flare up is extensive, speak to your doctor to find an alternative acne treatment. It‚Äôs worth noting that the progesterone only pills and the contraceptive implants can sometimes worsen acne, so do consider this when looking at contraceptive options.

story: NewsIncredible le of toddler travelling world who has already seen  countries aged Eric Ceclan has been travelling around the world since June last year and wont stop until he starts schoolShareCommentsByAlex Jones:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsEric overlooking Cura√ßao, a Dutch Caribbean island "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA toddler has already visited five continents and  countries - and hes not even three.Alina and Andrei Ceclan, from Cluj-Napoca, Romania, said they got sick of the routine and started travelling around the world with their two-and-a-half-year-old in June last year.The tot has already beat most adults to visiting some of the worlds most breath-taking sights, including Machu Pichu, temples in Thailand and the Kennedy Space Centre in Florida. story: NewsMeet the family living with  animals ‚Äì including a -stone hand-fed TIGERPetr August√øn and his family in the Czech Republic live with a host of dangerous animals from monkeys and meerkats to cougars and tigersShareCommentsByDanny BaggottKelly-Ann Mills:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video meet-family-who-spend-days-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family has spent the last ten years living with  animals including a -stone tiger, which is hand-fed and cuddled every day. title: mum drops four dress sizes
story: NewsMum drops four dress sizes and five-stone despite suffering from crippling arthritisEimer Fitzgerald would live on processed food and take-outs but resolved to lose weight after her babys christeningShareCommentsByRebecca Drew:,  FEB NewsEimer Fitzgerald would indulge in comfort food while growing up because she was being bullied "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum-of-one suffering from arthritis and who described herself as a yo-yo dieter has finally managed to shed a whole five stones in as little as two years.Nutritional therapist and health coach, Eimer Fitzgerald, , from County Tipperary, Ireland, was overweight most of her le because she would find comfort in food while being bullied. I have always been overweight from a young age, Eimer, who used to live on take-outs and processed food, she said. I used food as a coping mechanism for being bullied which spiralled into my adult le. I was very unhappy within myself and day to day things felt like a struggle for me.  Eimer, who described herself as a typical yo-yo dieter, joined slimming groups and tried a iety of diets.But because of her arthritis requiring weekly steroid injections that are known to increase hunger, she would struggle to stick to them in the long run.The mum said she finally resolved to shed weight after seeing pictures of her daughters christening five years ago at st lb and a UK size . She said she started studying nutrition and that worked for me. Thanks to more exercise and a healthier diet, Eimer is now st lb and a UK size .  Now I feel great, I am a big believer in having a little bit of everything within your diet. I follow a well-balanced plan so it is sustainable, she added. Planning and preparation of food is key. I also joined the gym three days a week which is hard to manage now with my psoriatic arthritis, but I keep active with walking and hoping to work my way back to the gym. Psoriatic arthritis is a type of arthritis that develops in some people with the skin condition psoriasis. It causes joints to become swollen, stf and painful. It is a long-term condition that can get progressively worse but with the correct treatment and diagnosis this can be slowed down.  Before her weight loss, Eimer would skip breakfast and have a breakfast roll as a mid-morning snack, lunch of a sandwich, crisps and fizzy drink, dinner of an oven pizza, microwaveable meal or takeaway and would snack on chocolate, crisps and sweets. Now, she has porridge with almond milk and fruit syrup for breakfast, a lunch of homemade soup and a -calorie wrap filled with chicken salad, and chicken curry and pasta bolognaise for dinner, made from scratch with her slow cooker. She snacks on -calorie chocolates and rice cakes with natural peanut butter and strawberries  .  For Eimer, the most dficult thing about her weight loss was managing her appetite while taking the injections. The medication I am on can increase appetite so that was one problem I had and mainly keeping my head in the game as they say. You need to be strict but also not to deprive yourself, she said. People are very positive about my weight loss, wanting to know how I did it, was it hard and how I maintain the weight loss. If its what you really want make the first step, whether its to join a group, get help from a professional oryou are in the right mind frame anything can be achieved.  Three words I use frequently when helping people would be: balance, you need a good balance of food to keep you interested and satiated habit, over a period of timeyou keep at it, it will turn into more of a habit than a struggle and lastly routine,its in your le, you practice and keep going with it, it can be a routine where it becomes a lot more manageable.

story: Craig Curran is Dundee‚Äôs major fitness doubt for their Friday night clash with Hibs at Dens Park.The former Dundee United and Ross County striker played at Livingston last weekend but has been nursing a stomach problem since the draw with Kilmarnock a fortnight ago.He hardly trained last week and has been missing again over the past few days.‚ÄúCraig is very sore, he didn‚Äôt train all last week because of a stomach thing,‚Äù said boss Jim McIntyre.‚ÄúHe‚Äôs going to require a few days to get over it.‚ÄùIf it‚Äôs a case of wait and see with Curran, Jim is confident both Andrew Nelson and Andreas Hadenius will make it.Nelson had to come off after netting the equaliser at Livi when he aggrevated ankle and calf problems as he celebrated his goal.And Swede Hadenius was replaced early in the second half at the weekend after picking up a knock.Both, though, have responded to treatment and are expected to be fit for Friday.With four goals since his arrival from Sunderland last month, -year-old Nelson is the man of the moment at Dens.While the manager stresses the young attacker remains a work in progress, he‚Äôs been delighted with his performances so far.‚ÄúNelson is a goalscorer and I thought his finish at the weekend was excellent,‚Äù Jim added.‚ÄúIt looked ashe was stretching but he‚Äôs managed to generate it into the corner.‚ÄúAs I‚Äôve said before, he is raw. He still needs a lot of work, working with a partner and when to link and stuff but I‚Äôm delighted with his goals contribution so far.‚Äù

title: dundee boss mcintyre ready to cross swords with new hibs gaffer heckingbottom
story: Jim McIntyre and Paul Heckingbottom will cross swords for the first time in their managerial careers when Dundee and Hibs clash at Dens tonight.However, while Jim admits to knowing little of his opposite number, his knowledge of the team he‚Äôll be putting out means he‚Äôs not expecting too many tactical surprises.Hibs appointed Heckingbottom as the successor to Neil Lennon last week and he kicked off his time in Scotland with an Easter Road win over Hamilton Accies.While, in time, the Dee boss knows his opposite number will put his own stamp on the Hibees, right now he‚Äôs not expecting too many drastic tactical changes from the way they lined up under Lennon.‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know him but he got off to a good start and Hibs have good players. It‚Äôs going to be a tough game,‚Äù said Jim.‚ÄúHe‚Äôs got good options as well, you need to be able to handle that.‚ÄúWe know what players he‚Äôs got to work with and we know their strengths and weaknesses like we do most of the other squads in the league. It‚Äôs about making sure yours are better than theirs on the night, that‚Äôs how it is in football.‚ÄúWe are back at home in front of the cameras and want to put on a good performance.‚ÄùDundee go into the game boosted by last week‚Äôs vital win at Livingston that hauled them out of the bottom two in the top flight for the first time since late August.Again, though, the manager is stressing it‚Äôs where the team are at the end of the season that counts.‚ÄúWe could be back down there come Saturdaywe don‚Äôt keep it going.‚ÄúLivingston is gone now and now it‚Äôs all about this one.‚Äù

title: dundee united boss jim mcintyre wants to see side convert more chances
story: Dundee boss Jim McIntyre is delighted with the increased number of chances his team are creating ‚Äì now he wants to see a better conversion rate.The first half alone of Saturday‚Äôs win at Livingston saw the Dark Blues create nine scoring opportunities.But it wasn‚Äôt until after the break victory was secured thanks to efforts from Andrew Nelson and Scott Wright.There were several other close calls as Dundee pushed for the win and that pleased the gaffer.‚ÄúI‚Äôm very pleased but we‚Äôd like to take a few more,‚Äù said Jim.‚ÄúThe move for Paul McGowan‚Äôs chance in the second half was superb, there were  passes.‚ÄúPeople will not see that, they‚Äôll just see the last two or three passes but we kept the ball, we moved it.‚ÄúWe couldn‚Äôt get through them but we were patient and when that killer pass was on it was played. It was a great opportunity and things like that are really pleasing.‚ÄùAndJim was disappointed his players had to fight back from going a goal down after Livi had been reduced to  men, he was pleased with the resilience they showed.‚ÄúThe key message at half-time was don‚Äôt panic, keep trying to move the ball because we‚Äôve got  minutes to turn this around.‚ÄúDon‚Äôt try to do it in the first five minutes, keep moving the ball and use the man advantage, try to stretch them.‚ÄúWe went to Easter Road and were two goals down and came back, so there is that bit of steeliness in the team.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not going to happen every week, you‚Äôve got to go and earn it, go and demand it.‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôd prefer not to go behind.‚Äù

title: osman sow wants to play a part in dundee united gaining promotion
story: It‚Äôs been a slow start to le at Tannadice after his move from MK Dons but striker Osman Sow is certain his patience will pay off and he can play a part in helping Dundee United to promotion.The former Hearts man joined the Tangerines late on transfer deadline day but is yet to start for his new club.His appearance against Queen of the South at the weekend was his third off the bench as he regains his match fitness.The Swede, though, knows he has to be patient, especially with strikers Nicky Clark and Pavol Safranko finding the net regularly at the moment but he‚Äôs happy to see the club picking up wins ‚Äì evenhe has to sit and watch most of them.He said: ‚ÄúPavol and Nicky are scoring but, at the end of the day, it is a team sport. If they score I am happy andwe keep winning I am happier!‚ÄúI just have to be patient and enjoy being part of this team.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been good so far.‚ÄúIn the last year I‚Äôve not played a lot of football so now I‚Äôm just enjoying training and being part of the team.‚ÄúI played for a month or so at MK Dons before I came here but it‚Äôs all good.‚ÄúI am feeling better and better every day, every day is a step in the right direction and I just need to play more and more football.‚ÄúI am happy as long as we keep winning.‚ÄùSow scored  goals for Hearts as they won the Championship back in  so he knows exactly what is required to go all the way and get back to the top flight.The - victory at Palmerston at the weekend was a dficult afternoon, particularly in the second half when the  men of Queens put the United rearguard under pressure.Sow, though, is only worried about one thing ‚Äì racking up another win to move a step closer to their goal.He said: ‚ÄúAt the end of the day, it‚Äôs the three points that matter.‚ÄúPalmerston is a tough place to go to but we managed to see the game out and we‚Äôre pleased with it.‚ÄúEverybody is happy, it‚Äôs all about winning the games and, as long as we keep getting the three points, it‚Äôs good.‚ÄúIt is dficult to win any league, to get promoted from any league no matter where.‚ÄúIt is about making the most of every day and not getting ahead of ourselves.‚ÄúWe need to train well every day and then win on Saturdays.‚ÄùAfter working with the striker in his time as Jambos manager, United boss Robbie Neilson was quick to take him south with him when he took the reins at English League One side MK Dons.That didn‚Äôt work out in the end for either but that‚Äôs not stopped Robbie moving again for the -year-old.And that repeated backing of his ability gives Sow enormous confidence ‚Äì a backing he is keen to repay as soon as he can by helping the Tangerines to the Premiership.He added: ‚ÄúDefinitely, I enjoy working with him and Dundee United are a good club who deserve to be in the top ision so it all felt good.‚ÄúI‚Äôm here now and it‚Äôs about taking every day at a time and trying to get over the line to where we want to be.‚ÄúI enjoy the manager‚Äôs way of working and his football and I believe in what he is doing.‚ÄúDefinitely it gives me confidence that he‚Äôs signed me and I‚Äôm just trying to give back to him.‚ÄùAnd Sow hopes he can begin to do that against Falkirk this coming weekend.‚ÄúI‚Äôll see what happens for the Falkirk game but the most important thing is we keep winning and the time will come for me to play my part.‚Äù

title: tom duthie deeiy sos then dundee boss jim mcintyre is the man to call
story: Rather understandably, no one has asked Jim McIntyrehe‚Äôs a fan of the hit BBC show DIY SOS.Perhaps we should, becausehe leads Dundee to safety this season he might just be able to lay claim to being the Scottish Premiership‚Äôs version of its presenter Nick Knowles.For those lucky enough to watch only football on the box, it‚Äôs the one where Knowles and a team of tradesmen step in to help families or groups with building projects they don‚Äôt have the knowhow or resources to complete on their own. To add to the drama, it‚Äôs done as a race against the clock.And McIntyre is gaining a growing reputation for doing the same with top-flight clubs here.Four-and-a-bit years ago he arrived at Ross County with the Highland outfit seemingly already doomed to relegation.By the end of that season he hadn‚Äôt just kept the Staggies up, he‚Äôd rebuilt them into a squad that would go on and win silverware in the shape of the  League Cup.After the Dark Blues‚Äô weekend win at Livingston got them out of the bottom two for the first time since the end of August, thanks to goals from new handy men Andrew Nelson and Scott Wright, there are strong signs he can do the same at Dens Park.McIntyre‚Äôs reign as Dundee boss started in October when he received an SOS from owner Tim Keyes and managing director John Nelms.After a miserable start to the campaign, the Americans‚Äô dream of cementing their team as a force in the Premiership and, eventually, taking the club to a new stadium looked in danger of crumbling around them.Confirmation of just how dire the need for an emergency rebuild came in his first game in charge when the roof fell in during a - defeat at Livi. It showed how flimsy the foundations of the team were as they collapsed under the weight of the home team‚Äôs excellence at set-pieces.Almost exactly four months on and after that second visit to the Tony Macaroni Arena under the new boss, the structure looks much more sound.And it‚Äôs all thanks to the kind of speedy reconstruction he undertook at County and of which Knowles and his team would be proud. For the team that ran out against Livi at the weekend bore no resemblance to the one McIntyre had to work with when he first headed there.Not one of the players in the starting XI in October were on from the start this time and of the  who were involved on that first day,  have left the club.Only Kenny Miller, Cammy Kerr and Elliott Parish remain and, of those three, veteran Miller was the sole participant in the vital - victory.For McIntyre, to bring about almost a complete change in such a short space of time has been a gamble, one that will only be confirmed as paying offhis team are still in the Premiership come the end of the season.It‚Äôs one, though, that represents his best chance of success and it is very much a case of so far so good.While Dundee under him remain a work in progress, the signs of improvement have been there for all to see.Since the end of the winter break there have been two wins, two draws and just one defeat in five league outings.By some margin that‚Äôs been the best run of form in the top flight so far this term.If it continues there is every reason to believe that target of building a team good enough for this level by the end of the season will have been achieved.Andthat is the case, fans will be hoping given more time, the manager will be able to set about putting together something even more impressive for next season and beyond.

title: Cyclists gather pollution data in Inverness
story: CLEAN air campaigners have strapped pollution sensors onto their bikes to expose the cityrsquos toxic air hotspots.The Highland Cycle Campaign is working with a student-led research project from Cambridge University to monitor air quality near roadways because of fears official figures are not capturing ldquodangerous levels of pollution.So far six members have used the pound monitors in ious areas including the A trunk road.And there are plans to extend its reach to the rest of the Highlands.Secretary Anne Thomas, who acts as local co-ordinator for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said the devices are showing where the most polluted areas are.She said: ldquoThe first maps show pollution levels on Academy Street and at the Longman roundabout as particularly high.And she claimed that the levels did seem, in some cases, to be breaching standards ldquowhich should have been met in .She added: ldquoIn reality there is no safe level of pollution which is responsible for thousands of premature deaths a year across Scotland.Mrs Thomas hopes the findings inspire more people to cycle as studies show car drivers spend longer in toxic air than walkers or cyclists on main roads.Friday  Feb  : PM

being a valuable resource centre for the Christian community it was a very popular place for people to come in for a coffee and to enjoy some fellowship, she said, adding that its resources will title: Inverness firm says Brexit is making customers cautious

title: Roads not safe for city cyclists says Inverness campaigner
story: A LOT needs to be done to bring roads in Inverness up to a standard that makes them safe and easy for road users to navigate, a leading cycling campaigner has said.Brian MacKenzie, convener of the Highland Cycle Campaign, said: ldquoI cycle a lot and there is no doubt the roads in the town are in very poor condition.ldquoThe trunk roads, too, need attention.Championing the cause for better and safer routes for cyclists he said drivers also need to be aware of cyclists and give greater consideration to them.ldquoDrivers often criticise cyclists when they see them weaving along certain routes but often they are doing that simply to avoid potholes and are taking evasive action, he said.ldquoAt the Raigmore Interchange, on the ramp joining the A south from the A, there is a pothole which has been there for some time. It is now gathering water and there is a warning sign for traffic alerting them to flooding.ldquoThere are also two more long potholes which are much more dangerous for cyclists and motorists just as you enter the interchange off the northbound ramp, coming from the Beechwood direction of the A.ldquoThe seal between the interchange and the ramp has gone andyou are cycling along there on a dark night you canrsquot see it, so your wheel can get caught up in it. These are like tram lines and they could throw you off a bike and cause serious injury.ldquoEvery vehicle coming from the A has to go across these potholes as they enter the interchange as well and they have been like that for a considerable time.ldquoI am wondering when the trunk roads people are going to carry out these repairs.While Highland Council is responsible for the upkeep of most roads in Inverness and the surrounding towns and villages, Bear Scotland is responsible for trunk roads.A spokesman for the organisation told the Courier last week that major defects, including deeppotholes which could pose a danger to road users, are repaired within  days, with safety inspections of all roads under its care inspected on a weekly basis.Friday  Feb  : PM

title: Sugars night set to be sweet for Highland Hospice
story: AN evening of fun, quality entertainment and good food has been promised by an Inverness man who is raising money for the Highland Hospice.Alastair Kennedy, communications director at Global Energy Group and chairman of Nigg Skills Academy, is calling on local businesses to try and help with his fundraising for this yearrsquos Strictly Inverness dancing competition.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom hoping that the business community will support this amazing cause as they have done in the past.Known to his friends as Sugar, Mr Kennedy will be hosting a dinner called Sugarrsquos Strictly Big Night at the Kingsmills Hotel in Inverness on April .The black tie tartan event will consist of live music from local band Torridon as well as an auction, quiz and a raffle, with all proceeds going to the hospice.Mr Kennedy is reaching out to the local business community to come along and support the event so he can raise as much money as possible.The director of Ross County Football Club is well known for his enjoyable hosting of hospitality at their home matches over the past  years, and thinks he has the the expertise and dry sense of humour to host another entertaining and enjoyable evening for all.As the oldest ever competitor in Strictly Inverness, Mr Kennedy was inspired to get involved in this yearrsquos event after sadly losing his mother to cancer in . I said at the time that I must, at some point in the future, do something to raise much-needed funds for the hospice, and with it being their th Strictly anniversary year, I just thought maybe now is the time.ldquoThere are lots of couples competing for the Strictly Inverness title and there is already great camaraderie being built up between us all.ldquoThis is not so much about winning, itrsquos more about raising money for this most worthy cause and everyone is working so hard not just in dance training, but in raising money by whatever means. I am hoping my business connections will assist me in being able to create a great night, but also raise as much money as possible for the hospice.Tables cost pound for  people and anyone interested should contact Mr Kennedy via Global Energy Group.Strictly Inverness also raises money for Inverness Ice Centre, which hosts the showdown from May .Friday  Feb  : PM

title: aberdeen baby battling complex medical issues one step closer to going home

title: investigation boy 7 saved from aberdeen schools swimming pool
story: An investigation has been launched after a young boy with additional support needs plunged into a swimming pool during a school disco.The seven-year-old pupil, from Orchard Brae in Aberdeen, ended up in the water in his unorm and had to be rescued.Today the boy‚Äôs dad called for answers and hit out at school staff for letting his son out of their sight.‚ÄúHe cannot swim and he could have died,‚Äù he said.The boy‚Äôs parents did not know about the incident until he came home in dferent clothes.The dad said when his son got home he appeared calm, but they were unable to seehe was unwell.He added: ‚ÄúHe was wearing his change of clothes and his escort, who brings him home, had no idea why.‚ÄúWe had to phone the school to find out he had gone out of the disco and got into the pool, during a swimming lesson.‚ÄúWhen he got home, we had no way of knowing whether he had water in his lungs or needed medical treatment.‚ÄúThe school never even told us who got him out of the pool or whether he was seen by a doctor.‚ÄúIt shouldn‚Äôt have happened, but they should be talking to parents after things like this do happen.‚ÄùThe school, on Howes Road in Bucksburn, teaches children with additional support needs and opened in July  after being built at a cost of ¬£. million.The boy‚Äôs family are questioning why school staff did not manage to stop their son getting to the pool.The dad said: ‚ÄúI could understandit was a normal class but there was supposed to be one member of staff for every student. How on earth did he get out ‚ÄúThey must put measures in place to avoid it happening again.‚ÄùAberdeen City Council said the circumstances of the incident, which happened on Tuesday, are being looked into.A spokeswoman said: ‚ÄúFirst and foremost we are happy to confirm that our pupil came to no harm.‚ÄúWe are undertaking an investigation into the incident and are in contact with the family.‚Äù

title: dancing brings light and beauty amid the grief to ardfern
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is¬† only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Laura MaxwellWithin This Dust is an interpretive dance performance inspired by the most horrying incident of our time: the   terror attacks.A packed Craignish Village Hall held host to the Dundee-based Shaper Caper performance on Wednesday February .Inspired by photographs of the   fallout, choreographer Thomas Small has created a performance that has been seen to bring tears due to its beauty and the tragedy of this story. First performed in , Within This Dust has gone on to be staged all over the UK and internationally, including at the   memorial and museum.Especially inspired by Richard Drew#s unforgettable photograph, The Falling Man, Within This Dust details the experience of witness, Lisa Hood, and victim, Vince Virr, of the   attacks.The witness finds herself surrounded in dust, made of crumpled paper, and begins a grieving process of hunting through the papers, finding meaning in the words, as someone tries to tidy around her. The second act features the victim joining the witness, creating a connection that will inevitably be broken, when finally, in the third act, the victim is alone, caught between a choice of the smoke and fire within the collapsing building or the  metre drop to freedom.It was a very poignant performance, tenderly expressing the horror of the incident, perhaps now weakened due to overindulgence. When the lights came up everyone stayed where they were, perhaps a little too stunned to move. Chatter was in whispers, for respect to people who could not hear them.As the narrator of the show captured and pieced together from coverage of the attacks said, the dust has not settled, and never will. The losses of the people in the planes and buildings is still felt, and the wider western world is still wary, still learning, still recovering.Within This Dust manages to depict the horror of that day beautully, and more importantly, delicately. No easy task for a grieving world.PIC:Craignish Village Hall was full. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood amongst the #dust#. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Lisa Hood. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood collecting dust. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood and Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustVince Virr facing the smoke, or the window. _aWithinThisDust

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is¬† only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of ¬£m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at ¬£.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of ¬£m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and ¬£m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising
