title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Friday  Feb  : PM

title: Delay to Wick 20 mph speed limit plans
story: THE brakes have been put on plans to introduce a  mph speed limit on the majority of roads in Wick.The proposal was mooted by Highland Council as a way to improve road safety and encourage walking and cycling.However, Wick members of the Caithness committee this week described the scheme as "a blunt instrument" and said other measures to reduce speed would be more effective. They also felt the consultation period should be extended by three weeks to allow the public more time to respond to the plan.Speaking at the meeting in Wick Town Hall on Wednesday, Councillor Nicola Sinclair said she was "very much in favour" of improving road safety but was concerned about the scale of the  mph limit and claimed there should be a longer period of consultation."The consultation took place over the Christmas period and I dont think people got enough opportunity to get their views heard," she said.Full report in Fridayrsquos John OrsquoGroat Journal.Friday  Feb  : PM

story: Wick weather expert Keith Banks reported that the town experienced its second warmest day for any February since  as the temperature peaked at .C .The current record for highest temperature in the town for the month is .C , recorded on February , .Keith said: ldquoThursday also saw the Scottish record for highest February temperature being broken when .Cwas reached at Aboyne. The previous highest temperature for February in Scotland was .C , recorded on February , .ldquoThe remarkable weather has been caused by a southerly airstream that is sourcing warm tropical air from the region of the Canary and Cape Verde Islands off the coast of north-west Africa.Friday  Feb  : PM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Friday  Feb  : PM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Friday  Feb  : PM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Friday  Feb  : PM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Friday  Feb  : PM

title: accessibility top of the agenda for northlink
story: Changes are being made by NorthLink Ferries to make their services more accessible to all.On board¬†information workshops and the introduction of new website software are the latest efforts being made by the company to improve services for those with additional support needs.The¬†ferry operator implemented its new Recite Me accessibility tool on its website, this month, to make it more suitable to folk#s needs. The new software ‚Äî which can be used on desktops and mobile browsers ‚Äî allows website visitors to customise what they see and hear, from changing the contrast settings, language, font size and more.In the UK, there are estimated to be . million people with a learning disability and . million people who have English as a second language. ‚ÄòRecite Me‚Äô has the ability to translate the NorthLink Ferries website into more than  languages ‚Äî including¬†Scots Gaelic . It can also translate text-to-speech to help visually impaired users and focus screen areas for those with dyslexia.On Monday, February , teams on board MV Hamnavoe hosted an Access Panel Orkney session, where staff were provided with disability awareness training. During the two-hour session, staff were able to experience what it‚Äôs like to have a disability by wearing glasses that simulated blindness, used wheelchairs and crutches and had their hearing dampened.Carolyn Grfiths of Access Panel Orkney said: ‚ÄúThe aim of our session was to let staff experience disabilities first-hand so they can empathise with passengers‚Äô needs.#All of us running the training have a disability so we were able to provide first-hand examples of what accessible travel is like for us. We were delighted to be welcomed on board to provide this training and it‚Äôs great to see a company like Serco NorthLink Ferries take accessibility for passengers seriously.‚ÄùThe MV Hjaltland will also host a Making Connections workshop today, Friday, February . The workshop will look at how passengers navigate potential barriers when changing from one mode of transport to another. Making Connections brings disabled people together with transport operators to discuss, address and plan how travel connections can be made easier.Seumas Campbell, customer service director at NorthLink Ferries, said: ‚ÄúCatering for passengers with ying degrees of disability is an important part of our service provision. Whether they are using our website to book their journey, making a connection from other forms of public transport or coming on board one of our vessels, we believe that passengers should experience a service that caters to all their needs.‚ÄúThe new website software will allow visitors to customise what they see and hear and as more and more visitors from around the world choose NorthLink Ferries to travel to the Northern Isles, ‚ÄòRecite Me‚Äô is a great tool to help them plan and book their journey.‚ÄúOur workshops are also a great way in training our staff on how they can best help and understand passengers‚Äô needs. We pride ourselves on having a great team that always provides the best service so it‚Äôs important that we‚Äôre constantly refreshing their training.‚ÄùFor more information on accessibility for passengers on NorthLink Ferries, you can visit¬†www.northlinkferries copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: council issues kirkyards apology
story: Orkney Islands Council has made an official apology following public concern about the way the county#s kirkyards are being managed.Distraught families and dismayed public officials have spoken out in recent weeks, after a scheme to improve the safety of cemeteries triggered reports that headstones were being laid flat without relatives being notied.Last week, a council insider told The Orcadian that ‚Äî in failing to contact families ‚Äî the council was disregarding government guidelines on cemetery maintenance.‚ÄúIt says it‚Äôs good practice to inform the families and give them an opportunity to repair the memorial, and that‚Äôs just not being done at all,‚Äù the inside source said.The Orcadian also heard from Stewart Spence, whose father#s headstone had been laid down in the Sandwick kirkyard with no notication from the council. This was despite the fact that the name and address of the person they needed to contact ‚Äî his mother Edna ‚Äî was engraved on the memorial.#Vandals couldn#t have done a better job,# he said.Following this wave of public concern,¬†OIC convener Harvey Johnston and chief executive Alistair Buchan have now released a statement apologising for the concern and upset that this project has caused.#Following a tragic accident involving a young child at a Glasgow cemetery, the Scottish Government asked councils to carry out detailed inspections in the interests of public safety,# they said.#We therefore engaged in the kirkyard safety programme for all the right reasons, but recognise that the process we have followed needs to be improved. It was never envisaged that the resulting work would leave kirkyards in the condition they are in. We are sorry about the concern and upset this has led to.#As a caring organisation, responsive to public concern, we will restore kirkyards to the condition people would expect. We will also consider how best to contact and discuss the remedial work required with those concerned. People‚Äôs safety is an important concern for us and we will continue to carry out headstone inspections. As at Warebeth , we will use blue pegs to mark stones identied as being unsafe and highlight these to local community representatives.#These stones will not be touched until we publicise the inspection results and give relatives the time they need to discuss with us any work they might wish to carry out themselves.#The statement also confirmed that further updates from the council will be provided further updates over the weeks ahead.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: german fleet salvage sites archaeology project results published online
story: With the centenary of the scuttling of the German High Seas Fleet in Scapa Flow fast approaching in June of this year, a fascinating insight into remains of aspects of the wrecks has now been published online.Historic Environment Scotland commissioned the Orkney Research Centre for Archaeology and SULA Diving to complete a full survey of the wrecks and debris remaining on the sea bed following the inter-war salvage operations.The seven remaining ships of the High Seas Fleet have seen Scapa Flow become one of the most well-known e sites in the World. Those wrecks are still the primary focus of recreational ers, but the remains of the vessels that were mostly recovered and removed from Scapa Flow have also been a recognised ing resource for many years.However, the exact extent and composition of these so-called salvage sites was unknown until this week, when the report of the second phase of work on these sites was published online.The overall aim of the Scapa Flow Salvage Sites Project was to determine what remains of the many vessels of the German High Seas Fleet that were salvaged in the years that followed their scuttling in June .Phase One, undertaken over the winter of  , involved a side scan sonar survey of the main anchorages and other areas thought to have been involved in the salvage process.In the second phase of this project, ers and remotely operated vehicles examined and recorded the remains in detail.The overall result is that the vast majority of salvage sites in Scapa Flow have been located and the remains at each site have been directly investigated and recorded.The full report is now available for public download through the Scapa Flow Historic Wreck website http:www.scapaflowwrecks projects salvage-sites-phase- Further details in The Orcadian on Thursday.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: in the footsteps of dr john rae
story: Next month will see a group of intrepid adventurers undertake a -mile mission in the Canadian Arctic, retracing the footsteps of one of Orkney#s most renowned, yet also overlooked, sons ‚Äî Dr John Rae.The Arctic Return expedition will see a four-man team set off from Naujaat ‚Äî also known as Repulse Bay ‚Äî in late March, aiming to retrace the footsteps made by the surgeon, explorer and surveyor in .It was on that expedition that the explorer finally discovered an open channel to the east of King William Island in the high arctic. Known today as Rae Strait, it was the missing link in what would become the first navigable Northwest Passage.He also reported back on the ill-fated Franklin expedition, reported evidence of cannibalism ‚Äî findings which were effectively rejected by the then establishment, and which led to Rae#s achievements being almost completely ignored.The modern-day team, who hope to raise further awareness of these achievements, will be led by Scottish-born and Canada-based expedition leader David Reid, with Scotland also represented by Broxburn-based former Royal Marine Richard Smith.The team will also include two Canadians ‚Äî adventure film-maker Gerry Tutte and adventurer Frank Wolf.Over  years later and supported with modern-day kit from outdoor specialists Tiso, the explorers are hard at work preparing for the physical and mental challenge of hauling kg sledges for nine hours daily and for up to  consecutive days.Their route will cover undulating, windswept tundra, river valleys and sea ice during what can be the coldest time of year.The Arctic expedition will finish once the four explorers have finally reached Gjoa Haven on King William Island.Mr Smith said: #The Arctic Return expedition will be extremely tough but ultimately our aim is to raise awareness fo the exploits of John Rae and to help restore his rightful place as one of the greatest Scottish explorers in history. It is also our hope that this awareness will inspire the public to support fundraising efforts by the John Rae Society, to restore Rae#s birthplace at the Hall of Clestrain in Oprhir.The team have said any addition funds raised are to be used to produce a documentary film and book about the le and exploits of Rae, the expedition and the history communities, culture and wildle of the Arctic.The public will be able to track the team#s progress at their official website and through social media.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mcarthur welcomes fuel poverty re think
story: Orkney‚Äôs MSP, Liam McArthur has welcomed Scottish Government plans to ensure that its Fuel Poverty Bill recognises the higher costs faced by those living in remote rural and island areas.During the stage one debate in Parliament yesterday, Wednesday, the Housing Minister, Kevin Stewart indicated that he would bring forward amendments to the bill to include an ‚Äòuplt‚Äô to the minimum income standard for rural and island communities. Mr McArthur believes this reflects a change in approach by the government, after months of campaigning by the Orkney MSP and a range of organisations involved in tackling fuel poverty across the Highlands and Islands.During his remarks, Mr McArthur pointed out that when it comes to fuel poverty, rural and island areas are disproportionately affected, with Orkney having the highest proportion of households in fuel poverty and extreme fuel poverty anywhere in Scotland.Commenting after the debate, Mr McArthur said: ‚ÄúFuel poverty blights communities across Scotland, but there is no doubt that it has a disproportionate impact on rural and island areas. Until recently, however, the Scottish Government appeared unwilling to recognise this fact or indeed the higher costs faced by those living in our rural and island communities.‚ÄúOver recent months, working with a range of organisations with a wealth of experience and expertise in tackling fuel poverty, I have made the case for the Minister, Kevin Stewart to think again. ¬†It was a case that the Local Government Committee was also persuaded to support.‚ÄúI am delighted, therefore, that the Minister has had a change of heart and committed to bring forward amendments to his bill at stage two that better reflect the specic nature of fuel poverty in places like Orkney. ¬†I look forward to seeing the detail of those amendments and will work with Mr Stewart, and local stakeholders in Orkney, to make sure we get this right.‚ÄúGiven the impact fuel poverty can have, not just on people‚Äôs quality of le but their physical and mental health, this bill has the potential to make a real dference. ¬†For that to happen, it must be both effective and ambitious in eradicating fuel poverty from communities across the country.‚Äùcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Black Isle authors French connection helps ensure nothing is lost in translation
story: Vee Walkers Major Toms War, partly set in France during WWI, is now fittingly being translated into French for a new edition of the book.Such has been the response to the novel that the Black Isle author has already been on a book tour and visited France on the back of it. The annual Franco-Scottish Society Alexander Gray Fund Lecture in Inverness on Friday promises to be alight-hearted bilingual talk from Ms Walker and her "long-suffering" Parisian translator Richard Kausch.Major Tomrsquos War is a moving novel set in France during the First World War, in part in the grim lsquozones occupeacuteesrsquo of northern France.Its characters are real people ndash and both author and translator have had to enter the minds of the novelrsquos key protagonists.The novel is published in English by Kashi House in London and the French edition should follow late this year or early in .Veeand Richard will be touring four of the regional Franco-Scottish Societies of Scotland this month.The groups exist to foster French language and culture in Scotland and meet monthly for French conversation or a lecture.Those who come along are welcome to join or to attend as a non-member. They are suitable for Higher Advanced Higher French pupils and their teachers.Vee confesses that as a French-speaking author she has not madeher translatorsle any easier: "Most translators produce a translation and the author would not have a clue about whether or not it is representative or accurate."My first degree was in French and although I am not a native speaker, I have had an opinion on nuance and vocabulary right the way through."Richard is currently revising the French text a second time to address the changes requested by my English publishers for the First Edition. He has the patience of a saint and I donrsquot know what I would have done without him!"Wersquore both looking forward to meeting audiences in Aberdeen, Edinburgh, Glasgow and Inverness on our tour around Scotland very much."Vee and Richardrsquos final tour slot is in Inverness on Friday, February  at the Glen Mhor Hotel,  Ness Bank, Invernessat .pm.Thelecture is free and will be followed by a French meal atpm. Theres a fixed menu.Reservations can be booked on   for lecture and or meal. title: Black Isle swimming pool is not yet sunk say supporters
story: DETERMINED campaigners fighting for a swimming pool dedicated to a fast-growing area of Ross-shire have succeeded in a last-ditch bid to keep the dream alive.The Ross-shire Journal last November told how activists behind a -year drive to establish a pool serving the Black Isle issued an appeal to a new generation to either take the plunge and get involved or see it wound up.The Black Isle Swimming Pool Foundationhas raised more than pound, and won planning approval for a new-build in Fortrose next to the existing leisure centre and secondary school.With anumber of BISPF stalwarts no longer able to continue driving the project, chairman Roy Sinclair appealed to Black Islers to grasp the nettle or wind up the foundation.A make-or-break project strategy meeting in Fortrose has seen a fresh commitment to push forward with a number of avenues to be investigated. These include:* A possible community buyout of the Black Isle Leisure Centre run by High Le Highland for Highland Council.* Appointing a business consultant to update the  business plan and probe funding applications.* Appoint a design team by competitive tender to revise the building plans and invite tenders.It was noted that the Black Isle remains a growing area with future housing and an expanding population.While a lottery bid for pound million towards the estimated poundm cost of the scheme failed back in , negotiations with the Scottish Land Fund via Highlands and Islands Enterprise to consider developing the project as a community enterprise company have continued.Mr Sinclair said: "A unanimous positive attitude was evident at the meeting which allows further progress to be made to develop this very important project for the benefit of folk on the Black Isle and beyond."A follow-up meeting is planned later this month.Whats your view  Email newsdesk@spp-groupFriday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Dingwall schools delight at 300 donation
story: A SPECIAL school in Dingwall has been the beneficiary of ldquoextraordinary community support after two local women managed to raise hundreds of pounds through a charity raffle.Mhairi Fazekas and Joanne Raeburn staged a Hogmanay raffle run through the Ross-shire Club which generated pound for the school.Around a dozen local businesses offered prizes including the Sports and Model shop, Edinburgh Woollen Mills, Strathpeffer golf club and Peppermint Beauty Salon, among others.Mrs Fazekas said: ldquoWe started selling tickets before Hogmanay and posted it on social media so when people found out it was for St Clements, it helped get people involved.ldquoPeople knowing that it was for St Clements definitely helped because Dingwall is a close-knit community and were more likely to be interested knowing that the money was going there rather than further afield.ldquoCertainly the school was very appreciative because they said it is dficult to raise money at that time of year and the kids were very excited wondering what the money would be spent on.Earlier, Christyna Ferguson whose daughter goes to the school, said the local community had offered the school ldquoextraordinary support over the years.She added: ldquoIt is unbelievable how good the support for St Clements is.ldquoI think people are proud of the school and what it does and want to see it improved.ldquoIt is just unbelievable, I have never seen anything like it.Friday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Gaelic milestone marked in Dingwall
story: Dingwall MSP Kate Forbes was among the guests from across Ross-shire as they recently celebrated the th anniversary of Gaelic services in the market town.Currently, services are held once a month in Dingwall Community Centre in Tulloch Street.To mark the special anniversary occasion, Rev Callum Macleod of Shawbost Free Church on the Isle of Lewis was the guest preacher.Ms Forbes said: ldquoCongratulations to the ministers and attendees of the monthly Dingwall Gaelic service.ldquoIt was a pleasure to join over  other people in Dingwall Community Centre to celebrate the th anniversary service.ldquoApart from the delicious cake and the thought-provoking sermon, I enjoyed the friendly camaraderie afterwards.ldquoThe Dingwall Gaelic service allows people to praise God and hear his word in their native language.ldquoIt is a shame that there are not more opportunities to do that, but I pay credit to the organisers of the Dingwall Gaelic service for their commitment to that.ldquoAll are welcome, and Irsquod warmly encourage others to attend on the first Sunday of every month at pm in Dingwall Community Centre.Friday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Highland Council investing extra in roads maintenance
story: Highland Council is hoping an additional pound. million for maintenance announced as part of this yearrsquos budget will make a ldquonoticeable dference across the region.The funding, approved as a priority area for the revenue budget, will be shared out across Highland with area committees able to decide how to prioritise it more locally.Chairman of the councilrsquos environment, development and infrastructure committee, Councillor Allan Henderson, said: ldquoWe have the most extensive network of roads in the UK and, added to this, we are faced with some of the most severe weather conditions in the Highlands.ldquoThe freeze-thaw conditions in particular cause immense damage to road surfaces and this is very evident in the past few weeks.ldquoRoad conditions are a high priority for local residents and this was very clear in our recent engagement with communities and local representatives.ldquoThe additional resource will, I hope, make a noticeable dference and can be allocated to the roads with the most urgent need of repairs, right across the Highlands.Area allocations based on road mileage and population are:Badenoch  Strathspey: pound, Caithness: pound,Inverness: pound, Lochaber: pound, Nairn: pound,Ross  Cromarty: pound,Isle of Skye: pound,Sutherland: pound,Friday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Invergordon ports plans put on public display
story: MORE than  members of the public took the opportunity to get a closer look at the Port of Cromarty Firthrsquos ambitious poundm expansion plans.The public information event in the port offices in Invergordon on Wednesday afternoon also allowed visitors to ask questions about the scheme. The port says the expansion is needed to maximise opportunities in the renewable energy sector and the cruise ship trade.Port marketing manager, Joanne Allday, said the response to the plans had been very encouraging.ldquoWe wanted to let people know what was happening, she said.ldquoIt was lovely to see so many people attending and taking an interest. There were lots of questions about how the project would progress, but people were very positive about it. They can see the benefits it can bring.Work has already begun on the quayside construction and is expected to run until March next year.The additional space will be used to assemble turbines for the Moray East Offshore Windfarm, but will also allow Invergordon, which is already Scotlandrsquos busiest cruise port, to accommodate the largest cruise ships currently being designed and built.This is the second quayside expansion at Invergordon in three years.Friday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Joy as Ross shire students win film prizes
story: GAELIC students from Ross-shire are celebrating after they were honoured in a nationwide film competition.Eilidh Johnson , from Dingwall, and Tain Royal Academyrsquos Jack Weir and Gordie Bryce were among the winners in the annual Gaelic film competition, FilmG.And Ms Johnson, who studies at Sabhal Mograver Ostaig in Sleat on Skye, had double the reason to celebrate after picking up two titles from three nominations. Her thought-provoking film Glaiste, a stop-motion piece about mental health, won best mobile short and also earned her the title of HIErsquos most promising young director. Her work was also one of the shortlisted finalists for best student film.Jack Weir and Gordie Bryce, meanwhile, were named best young filmmakers for their film Fagraveisneachd Dedrickabout a businessman struggling to come to terms with his wersquos death.Ross-shirersquos impressive representation in the finals also extended to Alness Academy, which made the shortlist for the FilmG award for Gaelic learners with its effort Gaol anns arsquo Chogadh . The title ultimately went where in the Highlands, after Millburn Academy won with their gripping film, Unknowing.The annual short film competition began in . It is run by MG ALBA and Cagravenan Graphics and was established to help the development of Gaelic through film.Murdo MacSween, communications manager at MG ALBA, said: ldquoI am over the moon with the quality of the films at this yearrsquos awards. It is wonderful to see so much young talent nurturing their Gaelic language skills ndash and being rewarded for it.Elsewhere among the Highland winners was Inverness man Calum MacLean, who won best industry director for his experimental film Fo Bhuaidh. title: Mystery oil tank artist adds a splash of colour to Invergordon
story: ITrsquoS a site steeped in local history and a lasting legacy to Invergordonrsquos nautical history.But the disused fuel tanks which stored the oil which powered some of the Royal Navyrsquos greatest warships during World War II has been a blight on the landscape of the Easter Ross port for generations.Recently, however, a graffiti artist has been hard at work beautying some of the relics, doing a lsquoBanksyrsquo with colourful images at the giant Seabank fuel tanks near the railway line, adding to lots of mural street art in the town already undertaken by the Invergordon Off The Wall group.Now the search is on to find the mystery painter who has already made a start on a canvas of over  massive tanks to choose from.Local woman Jacqueline Brown said she wasnrsquot sure exactly when the artwork was done: ldquoBut we would love to find out who is doing it.ldquoThe site really is out of bounds to the public but people go in and walk their dogs. I think I first saw the murals last year and they are quite stunning. Whoever is doing it is obviously very talented. Itrsquos a fascinating site. We know Invergordon became a naval town and was the base for the Home Fleet in World War I. These tanks were built for the supply of fuel to warships and they were in use until the mid-s.Mrs Brown said like many street artists, the person who carried out the work may wish to remain anonymous and even be fearful of prosecution.ldquoI just donrsquot know. But what they have done is quite beautul. I am sure we could find more projects for them in Invergordon including the town house which the community wants to take back into public ownership.A website documenting historical and derelict places in Scotland reveals the depot was built in conjunction with secret oil storage tanks a few miles away.It records the underground tanks were built to hold  million gallons of oil fuel and were built into a solid rock hill to protect it from bombs.On February ,  a Junkers  is reported to have carried out a solo attack on the tank farm, dropping two lb bombs damaging two tanks. But none of the bombs exploded although they cause a major spillage of oil.Mrs Brown said she understood there were plans to remove some tanks to build houses. She said: ldquoBut it takes time for these sites to be decontaminated from their former industrial uses.In , flats built in Joss Street had to be demolished because the site, which had been formerly used as a gas works, hadnrsquot been properly decontaminated.What do you think  Share your views by emailing us at newsdesk@spp-groupFriday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Port of Criomarty Firth to share details of expansion plan
story: DETAILS of the multimillion-pound expansion of the Port of Cromarty Firth will be unveiled to the publicthis week.The time frame behind the portrsquos ongoing pound million transformation, and efforts to grow its cruise ship trade and work within the energy sector, will all be discussed at an exhibition in Invergordon tomorrow.The event, which will run from pm to pm, is part of the portrsquos efforts to provide regular progress updates on how construction of the quayside expansion is going.Work began last month and is expected to run until March next year, ahead of the portrsquos planned involvement with assembling turbines for the Moray East Offshore Windfarm.A spokesman said: ldquoThe port has been ersying its offering over the past few years, to appeal to a wider range of business sectors and ensure we can create jobs and economic opportunities for the Highland region into the future.ldquoThis has included expanding from our traditional support for the North Sea oil and gas sector into renewable energy and cruise tourism.ldquoThe port has established itself as the waterborne tourist gateway to the Highlands. This positioning means that Invergordon receives more cruise passengers than any other port in Scotland, generating over pound million in tourist spend and hundreds of jobs within the wider Highland economy in . This will increase to pound million this year.The expansion was triggered by the successful award of a pound million contract from the Moray East Offshore Windfarm to use the site to assemble its turbines.The exhibition, which will be held at the port offices in Shore Road, will display the construction programme and timings of the expansion project and are welcome.AN experienced solicitor has joined the board of the port.Rhona Harper, who has worked for more than  years as a solicitor, is a procurement law specialist, experienced in developing and implementing innovative public private partnerships.For  years, she was a partner of the Scottish law firm Shepherd and Wedderburn during which team she managed a team of solicitors and support staff and led the firmrsquos Government and Public Sector Group.The board meets regularly to review the PoCFrsquos business and future plans. They are not owners or shareholders but manage the organisation which reinvests all its profits into the development of the Trust Port.Bob Buskie, chief executive of the PoCF, said: ldquoThe port is absolutely thrilled to bring Rhonarsquos vast experience to our board. We are lucky to have such a strong board that works well together. Rhonarsquos predecessor, Douglas Russell, will be a hard act to follow but we know that Rhona is up to the task.Port of Cromarty Firth board members can only serve a maximum of nine years.That however can be extended to  yearsthey serve as chairperson.They must be reappointed every three yearsthey wish to remain on the board.Friday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Ross shire pupil wins undisclosed sum from Highland Council after wall debris broke leg at school
story: Max MacPhee, aged seven, was injured by falling debris at Ben Wyvis Primary School in Conon Bridge.He was hospitalised with a broken leg and is now left with one leg cm longer than the other.Highland Council denied liability throughout a civil action but last week backtracked by offering an out-of-court settlement after Digby Brown Solicitors proved they knew of an earlier debris fall one year before Max was injured.While glad to win the case, mum Louise MacPhee , accused the council of acting ldquoshamefully.She said: ldquoItrsquos shocking that Highland Council didnrsquot have the common decency to hold their hands up and just help a little boy who was hurt by their own failings instead of having the audacity to try and blame him.Max was injured in May  when he was then aged five-years-old.He had been leaning on the wall after his morning nursery session when a coping stone detached and struck him on the right leg ndash breaking it just beneath the knee.Max spent two months in recovery most of which was spent using a wheelchair or a walking frame.His bed was placed in the living room as he couldnrsquot walk up the stairs and for the first few weeks of his recovery the youngster also had to be bathed by hand while lying on top of the kitchen counter because he couldnrsquot get in the bath.Louise, a bar maid from Conon Bridge, added: ldquoThe council put us through hell, not to mention wasted public money on legal bills, when they could just have done the right thing from day one.ldquoAt least now they can be held accountable and everyone will know their shameful tactics in blaming a little boy.ldquoIf therersquos any good to come from this then I hope itrsquos that the council give themselves a serious shake and invest in improving the safety of public areas so people arenrsquot hurt in the first place.David McGowan, associate at Digby Brownrsquos Inverness office, led the legal action against Highland Council.He said his investigations found the local authority was alerted to structure concerns at Ben Wyvis Primary when a coping stone fell from the same wall in .But despite this he claimed the council failed to carry out adequate inspections or repair work.Mr McGowan, who helped secure the undisclosed settlement, said: ldquoThis was clearly an accident waiting to happen and itrsquos distressing to consider how much worse Max or anyone  could have been injured.ldquoEvery local authority has a duty of care towards those entering their premises and this is especially important when considering schools and nurseries.ldquoSecuring rightful damages is just one aspect of how we help iniduals - the other is holding defenders accountable to hopefully improve safety standards for all.Asked for comment, a Highland Council spokeswoman said: ldquoIt is the councilrsquos policy not to comment on insurance claims.Friday  Feb  : PMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: chuka umunna just proved i was so wrong about him jim duffy
story: Chuka Umunna#s resignation from the Labour party shows his qualities include political bravery, writes Jim Duffy.They say that looking into the whites of peoples eyes can tell you a lot about them as human beings. Eyes being the window to the soul and all that. I like to feel the cut of an inidual‚Äôs gib before I truly get to know and trust them. None more so that with politicians. But, the opportunity to meet them just does not happen very often. Especially, the more high-profile types where their attendance is all a bit stage managed.However, as I write this piece today you can be assured that I am talking straight from empirical past experience. Over a five-year period, I was exposed ‚Äìthat is the correct term to describe it ‚Äì to a number of high-profile politicians and their entourage.During these, on many an occasion, intimate affairs, I got to see close up the man or the woman who I had seen on TV the day before or would see tomorrow on TV. Therefore seeing Chuka Umunna and Jeremy Corbyn this week on TV brought back some interesting and emotive memories, as I met them both and spent quite a bit of time with them.‚ÄúCoffee with Corbyn‚Äù can come at a later date as it is Mr Umunna who occupies my thoughts for now. I sat on a  with Chuka. It was a big event at the Glasgow Exhibition Centre. As usual, I arrived early. I like to do this to get a feel for the event, those exhibiting and those who have turned up to hear the speakers. I had a five-minute slot on stage and would then be part of the discussion . It was the headline event. But, just to be clear, it was not a party political event. Chuka Umunna arrived and was brought through to the ‚Äúgreen room‚Äù where the speakers were kept away from the crowds. It was just me and him for a brief period. He is not what I would call a big man, but he‚Äôs fairly athletic and looked like he kept himself pretty fit. He was wearing a sharp, tailored suit, crisp white shirt and he was clean shaven. In fact, it is fair to say he was immaculate. I said hello and shook his hand as he sat down beside me.: Ian Murray: Leadership of our party has pushed too many people to the brinkRushing through my mind and forcing its way into my thoughts, despite my best attempts to block it out, was my deep held perception that he was one of Tony Blair‚Äôs boys. In short, a Blairite.And in my book, that did not wash well as ‚ÄòMr Bliar‚Äô ‚Äì as he is referred to in the George Galloway documentary, the Killing of Tony Blair ‚Äì was most certainly not on my Christmas card list.But, I did try hard not to let this colour my thinking. We blethered about his journey up from England, then the  presenter, a well-known TV pundit, popped her head in and started gushing. Chuka this and Chuka that. It was like Alan Partridge drooling over a ‚Äògorgeous blonde‚Äô guest on his clever s satirical talk show, Knowing me, Knowing you.Anyway, by this time, I was most certainly playing second fiddle to Chuka, who with great charm and acceptance, gushed back at the TV pundit. And at this moment, I went off him. Despite being the friendly face who had chatted with him, I was now ‚Äúin the background‚Äù as he ramped up his persona for his keynote and the  discussion.Suffice to say, it all went swimmingly well, the audience seemed happy enough and Chuka and me never saw each other again.But, from that experience and then Chuka‚Äôs inept and cringeworthy go at throwing himself in the ring for the Labour Party leadership, I considered him spineless and just a slick-talking young politician who was just like his role model, Teflon Tony. My view of him was as one of those Westminster politicians who lived in the bubble and would stay there safe and secure for years, building up newspaper columns, books and slots on the speaking circuit.Until this week... Bloody Well Done Chuka Umunna!: David Mundell: SNP backing no-deal Brexit to break up UKGranted it has taken you some time to fall out of love with yourself and the Labour Party. But, never say never and it‚Äôs never too late to change.Watching Chuka walk out with his fellow Labour MPs, affirming their credentials and being brave, made me stop and think for a while. If I‚Äôm being honest, as I watched the live TV broadcast, I felt a bit emotional and wanted to throw my fist in the air with cry of ‚Äúyes, yes‚Äù. Not in any way, shape or form because  MPs had decided Labour was no longer for them or that Westminster politics was ‚Äúbroken‚Äù.No, I wanted to fist-pump as I had seen the young and bordering on arrogant politician I sat with, now grown up and being true to himself. I think amazing things could happen now. Chuka Amunna is clever, educated, considerate, experienced and a first-class communicator. But, what is more powerful and signicant is that he can now unleash all of this, in his own way, unbridled by the party whip. Years of frustration and figuring out who he is will now lead to a clear vision of what he truly wants his country and British politics to be like. But, don‚Äôt expect it overnight. It will take time and he needs to be supported, challenged and mentored. Notwithstanding, he is now ready and I bet fully prepared and focused on the task that lies ahead of him and his new colleagues.Your father Ben Umunna is not alive Chuka, buthe was here today, I‚Äôm sure he‚Äôd say one thing. I‚Äôm so proud of you son.¬©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings

title: scotland should heed wisdom of george washington about independents paris gourtsoyannis
story: Sorry, were having problems with our video player at the moment, but are working to fix it as soon as we canWaiting for Video...With all the Independent Group#s MPs from England, Scotland should perhaps consider a warning from the first US president, George Washington, about the dangers of unthinking loyalty to political parties, writes Paris Gourtsoyannis.There‚Äôs a group of disruptive, mould-breaking MPs on the opposition benches, shaking up Westminster and banging on about independence ‚Äì and for once, it isn‚Äôt the SNP. In fact, this week‚Äôs drama has had little,anything, to do with Scotland. The Tory defectors who joined this week talked about the one-nation Tory ideal, but so far, the Independent Group only represents one nation: England.All its MPs are from English constituencies ‚Äì although the ex-Labour member for Stockport, Ann Coffey, was born in Inverness ‚Äì and when you ask its members, breathless from endlessly talking about themselves, they don‚Äôt have much to say about Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland. Fair enough: they aren‚Äôt a political party, they don‚Äôt have any policies, and they haven‚Äôt been around for a week yet.Butthe MPs quitting their parties are tapping into something real ‚Äì a yearning for that clich√© of a ‚Äúdferent kind of politics‚Äù ‚Äì should Scotland be left out Let‚Äôs take the Independent Group at face value: part of the motivation for the breakaway is MPs saying ‚Äúenough‚Äù to unrestrained, extreme views in their parties.On that basis, Scotland could do with an Independent Group ‚Äì according to its own parliamentarians. Many SNP MPs are privately scathing about ‚Äúzoomers‚Äù in their own party, ‚Äúsome of whom have letters after their name‚Äù, as one put it. Another suggested they would welcome an early Scottish election as a chance to take on those demanding an immediate independence referendum, and ‚Äúget them out of the party‚Äù. It‚Äôs easy to imagine, in the first months of an independent Scotland, a parallel centrist breakaway from the SNP ‚Äì and the ‚ÄòGang of Seven‚Äô who would lead it.Scottish Labour isn‚Äôt a happy political family, either. Some of its most senior figures ‚Äì Kezia Dugdale, Ian Murray, Anas Sarwar and Jackie Baillie ‚Äì are shut out. Listen to the Scottish Tory Paul Masterton talk about a no-deal Brexit and it‚Äôs clear he‚Äôs as fed up with the ERG, too.: Paris Gourtsoyannis: Breakaway Labour MPs hope for Macron-style rise to powerLet‚Äôs be clear: it isn‚Äôt going to happen. At least not right away. Constitutional politics and tribalism go hand in hand Scotland knew this before the UK even joined the EU. Both are forces that generally keep people wearing the colours they already have pinned on ‚Äì and when they do change, the falling out is only bigger.Murray and Sarwar were brought up in Labour, and would only consider leaving in the direst of circumstances. At Westminster, the Scottish Tories are almost all just in the door and several are on track for ministerial jobs. At Holyrood, isions and uneven quality are smoothed over by Ruth Davidson‚Äôs brand and the possibility of power.The collapse of Scottish Labour means that for many, the beneficiaries in the Tories and particularly the SNP already fill the role of the insurgent ‚ÄòTIG‚Äô, as people are calling The Independent Group. Tellingly, ex-Tory MP Heidi Allen said: ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt leave the party, it left me.‚Äù Identical to Mhairi Black‚Äôs words about Labour.Contrary to what outraged Corbyn outriders claim on social media, there has been scrutiny of the contradictions in the Independent Group ‚Äì we know Anna Soubry thinks George Osborne‚Äôs economic policy was ‚Äúabsolutely necessary‚Äù because a journalist asked her. Andthere‚Äôs a sense of energy, optimism and timeliness around it, it‚Äôs inherent in what they‚Äôre doing.Listen to Allen and Luciana Berger speak and you can hear repressed anger, hurt and alienation finally being given a voice. Imagine quitting a rubbish job with lots of abusive clients and a senior management that hate you. It‚Äôs liberating to escape that kind of unhappiness.: Brexit exposes failings of UK‚Äôs political elite ‚Äì Paris GourtsoyannisWhether they succeed or fail on whatever terms they eventually set themselves, the Independent Group have tapped into something essential about politics today. Voters are less loyal and more sceptical towards establishment politicians and parties ‚Äì part of the reason why Corbyn is Labour leader at all.In unstable times, people want greater ersity and independence of thought, something reflected in the fragmentation of political groupings across the Western world ‚Äì a trend that the UK still lags behind in. Part of that is down to the UK‚Äôs voting system and constitution on the continent, there is far more experience of coalition-building and cross-party working, which is why the UK‚Äôs Brexit deadlock looks so weird viewed from Brussels.Political parties are all coalitions to some extent. Is it really more dficult to imagine a party that unites Anna Soubry and Chris Leslie than one that includes Soubry and Jacob Rees-Mogg  If the Independent Group ends up as a new party, I suspect it will be easier than many predict to develop a policy  that satisfies two branches of continuity Blairism: the former front benches of Ed Miliband and David Cameron.Question their motives, political backgrounds and effectiveness, but the basic principles of the Independent Group are venerable and sound. No less an architect of modern democracy than George Washington warned in his  presidential farewell address that party loyalty would ‚Äúdistract the public councils and enfeeble the public administration‚Äù and ‚Äúagitates the community with ill-founded jealousies and  alarms, kindles the animosity of one part against another, foments occasionally riot and insurrection‚Äù.Look at the state of debate in the country he helped found and the one it split from, and it‚Äôs hard to argue.Scotland‚Äôs political landscape is already crowded ‚Äì but it used to be even more so, with room for the Scottish Socialistsand even the Senior Citizens‚Äô Party. In Dennis Canavan and the late, irreplaceable Margo MacDonald, it has also had some of the UK‚Äôs most effective independent parliamentarians. When the time comes, Scotland ought to take a good look at independents.¬©JPIMedia Ltd. .Cookie Settings
